record:
A 75-year-old male retired accountant was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction due to complete occlusion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle after recent complaints of persistent mid-sternal chest pressure radiating to his left arm, accompanied by profuse sweating. 

 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESIS reveals that the symptoms started two hours prior to hospital arrival. At that time, it occurred without warning, and he noted his electrostatic discharge from a faulty appliance may have been responsible, as it happened around his residence on this particular evening at nine twenty PM. Despite a history devoid significant preceding factors he reported an unusually strenuous effort in lifting household equipment several hours before and possible episodes of palpable discomfort following.

His past medical history showed managed atrial fibrillation requiring anti-coagulant therapy including Eliquis 5 milligrams administered twice daily. Moreover, episodes of hyperlipidemia were recorded alongside the long term consumption and resultant addiction of Nicorandil tablets 5 milligrams administered three times a day since a diagnosis eight years prior for episodes resembling symptoms of variant angina.

This individual has a forty two pack-year historical use of combustible cigarettes and an average weekly intake equating three standard units or twenty one pints and also described social history notable for working with asbestos in a shipbuilding career spanning thirty nine years prior, resulting an appreciable history respiratory symptoms, albeit largely non-specific, often described as episodes wheezing after heavy inhalational exertion, and notably described chronic hypotrophic symptoms which are usually transient in duration following alcohol consumption and nicotine ingestion with symptoms typically relieved following a regimen comprising low doses diazepam.

His admitting physical examined documented him at being one eighty seven centimeters of height weighing seventy three kilograms with blood at the systolic being a recorded one forty millimeters and diastole a ninety. The results documented during routine physical also detailed notable tenderness located throughout the lower extremities, along abdominal walls that were non localized, along a notably tender mass on lateral chest and a systolic five decibel decrease in intensity of s1 in mitral auscultation. Noted abnormalities during electrocardiographic tracings, documented an axis deviation at plus fifty two. Significant ECG results also documented acute anterior and ST depressed in leads  V3-V6 in accordance T-wave inversions with low sensitivity noted during the monitoring periods for possible signs cardiac tamponade.  

Clinical blood data, comprising routine investigations showed the full blood picture was unremarkable. Notable electrolytes showed a slight hypo-kalaemia although other electrolytes were in the respective normal range as per standard deviation in clinical normal ranges alongside serum albumin results being marginally raised following a recent infection episode of prostatitis for which ofloxacin had been prescribed with satisfactory urine output with an elevated CRP result documented alongside mild hyponatremic effects in blood and urine analysis.

HIS subsequent and present Hospital course required intravenous medication therapy and strict fluid management protocols were promptly initiated on admission following episodes of documented cardiac compromise to alleviate symptoms experienced which had led him to the decision that hospital assistance may aid his symptoms that evening after failing to resolve with rest following onset several preceding house related events with resultant exertion on a particularly chilly autumn twenty fourth October day with significant exertion prior documented with clinical observations and monitoring being continued following hospital review.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The patient, a 72-year-old retired machinist, was admitted with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia and associated hypoxemia requiring supplemental oxygen therapy. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient had become symptomatic over the preceding week with gradually increasing cough, mild fatigue, and difficulty breathing, exacerbated by exertion. Initial management by the primary care physician included oral antibiotics and supportive care, which unfortunately did not yield the expected improvement. Consequently, upon clinical deterioration and given concerns for respiratory compromise, the patient presented to the emergency department for further evaluation and management.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
The patient has a long-standing history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, complicated coronary artery disease status post bypass grafting, hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Regular medications include aspirin, a beta-blocker, and an inhaled corticosteroid.

SOCIAL HISTORY 
Notably, the patient resides in a rural area, has a remote history of exposure to potential environmental hazards including prolonged smoking that was discontinued fifteen years ago, and consumes small amounts of wine on rare occasions. Functional capacity was remarkably preserved until this recent illness, with ability to participate in gardening activities and drive himself.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 
The admission examination showed vital signs reflecting significant hypoxemia with an initial oxygen saturation of 78 percent despite use of his home oxygen, temperature 39.1 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 155/91 mmHg. Relevant additional physical findings include the use of accessory respiratory muscles, mild jugular venous dilation, bibasilar end insulinpery rales upon chest auscultation, with preserved mental status.

LABORATORY DATA 
Pertinent initial studies were notable for a PaO2 of 45 mmHg on two liters of supplemental nasal oxygen, an elevated white blood cell count at 16,000, mild acute kidney injury, electrocardiogram indicating sinus tachycardia, chest radiography showing multifocal patchy bilateral lung opacities indicative of multifocal pneumonic infiltrates, which guided initiation and tailoring of antibiotics therapy and need for critical unit admission and noninvasive respiratory support with a toxic metabolic state also identified in the initial panel work requiring attention and correction to prevent any organ compromise and further decline.

HOSPITAL COURSE 
Initial intensive therapies for acute decompensation were well-tolerated by the patient after being adjusted, optimized for underlying heart disease while addressing current infection. Clinical condition improvement followed shortly including lessened symptoms of distress, reduced fever and resolution of some of the infiltrates on a chest repeat radiograph and a better preserved saturation level and also the kidney injury that had started improving gradually during treatment after close follow-up and management and after discontinuation of all possibly suspected medications that likely may cause such complications, which allowed the discontinuation of some critical care services.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 72-year-old retired schoolteacher who presented to the Emergency Department with a 24-hour history of worsening abdominal pain. Initially, the pain was diffuse but gradually localized to the right lower quadrant. She reported accompanying nausea, loss of appetite, and two episodes of non-bilious vomiting. She denied any fever or chills. The pain intensity increased over time, prompting the decision to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril 10 mg daily, and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she takes metformin 500 mg twice daily. She has a history of arthritis and takes acetaminophen as needed for joint pain. No prior history of gastrointestinal surgeries or similar abdominal episodes was reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a widow and lives alone in a one-story house. She has two adult children who live nearby and provide support. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, about twice a month. Her active lifestyle includes daily walks and participation in local community activities. She follows a diabetic diet to help manage her blood sugar levels.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared mildly distressed, with vital signs showing a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 145/82 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding and rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds were present but hypoactive. No palpable masses were noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory studies showed a white blood cell count of 13,000/mm³ indicating leukocytosis, hemoglobin level within normal limits, and elevated C-reactive protein. Electrolytes and renal function tests were within normal ranges. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, showing an enlarged, inflamed appendix without evidence of perforation.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the surgical floor and started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and metronidazole. She underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy the following morning. Post-operatively, she progressed well, with her pain managed effectively with oral analgesics. The surgical site showed typical healing progress without signs of infection. Her blood glucose levels were closely monitored and maintained within an acceptable range throughout her hospital stay. She was able to ambulate without difficulty by the second postoperative day and was advanced to a regular diet as tolerated. The patient was discharged on post-operative day three with instructions for wound care and a follow-up appointment with her surgeon in one week. She was advised to gradually resume her normal activities while avoiding significant exertion and heavy lifting.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is admitted with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
A 68-year-old retired teacher was brought to the emergency department by her granddaughter, presenting with symptoms of high fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The symptoms started three days ago and have been progressively worsening, with increased fatigue and chills. Initially, the patient self-medicated with over-the-counter cold remedies, but without improvement, the family sought professional medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient's past medical history is notable for hypertension, controlled on lisinopril 10mg daily for the last eight years, and type 2 diabetes, for which she takes metformin 500mg twice a day since diagnosis five years ago. Additionally, she underwent hip replacement surgery six years ago due to osteoporosis but has had no significant sequelae. The patient does not have a history of smoking but did experience a mild reaction to an MRI with a gadolinium-based contrast agent many years ago, necessitating careful selection of imaging studies.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient lives at home with her husband and grandchildren. Given her recent decline in mobility due to a torn meniscus from a fall, her activity level has been significantly decreased. The fall incident happened while out for a walk and resulted in several days of rest but did not necessitate surgical intervention at the time.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Upon physical examination, the patient is found to be somnolent but arousable to stimulus. She is tachypneic with use of accessory muscles, indicating substantial distress. Pulmonary auscultation reveals bilaterally decreased breath sounds with faint expiratory wheezling. Cardiac inspection and palpation show a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

LABORATORY DATA
 Laboratory data indicates elevated white blood cell counts and significant alterations in arterial blood gases consistent with acute respiratory alkalosis secondary to distress. The patient underwent an emergency thoracic X-ray due to difficulty in getting an immediate CT scan slot which would have provided more insights possibly altering the management plan had certain findings appeared indicating complications requiring closer monitoring and different approach. Initial results suggested bilateral consolidation which supports the clinical suspicion of pneumonia, for which broad-spectrum IV antibiotics were initiated along with other supportive respiratory care measures.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Over the hospital stay, the patient showed significant improvement in respiratory status and mental alertness, though required prolonged hospitalization to manage and wean off the non-invasive ventilation due to episodes of acute distress and desатураcia requiring readjustment of oxygen therapy and titrating of vasopressin dose. The treatment plan underwent revisions after incorporating subsequent investigations results for comprehensive assessment and adjustment where necessary and upon specialist input for optimized, personalized, multidisciplinary care approach to deal effectively various aspects, contributing in successful outcome at the eventual discharge time after ensuring stabilization.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease secondary to community-acquired pneumonia 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The fifty-two-year-old male patient presents with a four-day history of worsening shortness of breath and purulent yellow sputum production, prompting hospital admission due to increasing oxygen requirements. A smoker of twenty pack-years and currently trying to reduce his habit, the patient reports a recent two-week history of rhinorrhea and cough preceding his rapid respiratory deterioration.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: His medical history is significant for asthma in childhood and current managed hypertension, with daily usage of Lisinopril, which has been effective. The patient had an implant of a spinal cage eight years prior following a serious traumatic injury to L4-L5 vertebrae that was deemed necessary due to vertebral dislocation, and has shown no signs of complication other than localized stiffness upon waking daily.

SOCIAL HISTORY: An occupational roofer, he admits significant sun and airborne pollution exposure throughout his thirty-year career. His daily habit includes minimal morning stretching before proceeding to daily tasks, which predominantly revolve around heavy lifting. A moderate drinker but only on Friday nights after work, he otherwise lives actively, though lately less, while taking time off his busy work schedule only when necessary, often neglecting medical follow-ups.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon initial examination, vital signs show a temperature of 98.9 Fahrenheit and oxygen saturation of 85% on three liters nasal cannula. Physical inspection reveals coarse crackles upon auscultation bilaterally on lung fields but without added cardiac anomalies aside general bradycardia at sixty-five beats per minute and normal blood pressure of 127/76 millimeters of mercury.

LABORATORY DATA: His initial lab values are concerning for acute kidney injury stage II with an elevated creatinine to 1.6 milligrams per deciliter and white blood cell count elevated to 16 thousand, suggesting infection as an exacerbating factor among other parameters being essentially unremarkable. Serial lab assessments demonstrate improvement.

HOSPITAL COURSE: He began broad spectrum antibiotic and methylprednisolone, showing rapid clinical response with improved oxygenation and significant clearing of sputum after just seventy two hours into admission, and subsequent chest computed tomographic angiography displayed no concerning areas indicative for possible pulmonary embolism but mild left lower pulmonary segmental airspace consolidation consistent with an infectious process, leading his team towards continued respiratory weaning efforts with intensive physical therapy mobilizing his lower limbs post spinal surgery eight years prior. This helped prevent significant thrombombolic risks and the final plan prior to discharge focused upon follow-up appointment review of his lung function in clinic post recovery alongside smoking secession assistance classes for a healthier future.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: James Anderson, a 32-year-old software engineer, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of severe abdominal pain. The pain began as vague discomfort around his umbilical region but intensified to a sharp, persistent ache in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. He also reported experiencing nausea and a low-grade fever of 100.8°F. James noted that the pain worsened upon movement, and he was unable to find relief in any position, prompting urgent medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: James' medical history is notable for well-controlled asthma since childhood, managed with an as-needed albuterol inhaler. He denies any prior surgeries, significant illnesses, or hospitalizations. He has no history of hypertension, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY: James lives in Seattle with his partner and works for a tech company, where he spends long hours seated at a computer. He exercises sporadically on weekends by hiking with friends in the nearby Cascade Mountains. He smokes occasionally, particularly in social settings, and consumes alcohol moderately, typically about two to three times per week. He denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, James was found to be in moderate distress due to pain. He was afebrile with stable vital signs except for mild tachycardia. Abdominal examination revealed significant tenderness and guarding in the right lower quadrant with a positive rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds were hypoactive, and no masses or hepatosplenomegaly were noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm³, indicating leukocytosis. C-reactive protein was elevated. Liver function tests and kidney function tests were within normal limits. A urine analysis ruled out urinary tract infection.

HOSPITAL COURSE: James was admitted to the surgical unit with a diagnosis of acute appendicitis. A preoperative abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an inflamed appendix. He was counseled about the need for an appendectomy, to which he consented. He received intravenous antibiotics preoperatively. The surgical procedure was performed laparoscopically without complications. Postoperatively, James was monitored closely and experienced an uneventful recovery. Pain was managed adequately with acetaminophen. He was discharged on postoperative day two with instructions to avoid strenuous activity for a few weeks and to follow up with his primary care physician in one week for wound inspection. James was advised to gradually resume his daily activities and to seek medical attention should any fever, severe pain, or other concerning symptoms arise.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient, a 62-year-old male retired construction worker, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of severe hypoglycemia. He has a history of type 2 diabetes and was taking metformin and glyburide.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient reported that he had been feeling ill for the past two days with symptoms of confusion, dizziness, and Shakiness. He had been skipping meals due to a recent episode of gastritis, which led to a significant decrease in his blood glucose levels. The patient's wife stated that he became unresponsive while watching television, prompting her to call emergency services.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetic nephropathy. He has a history of smoking and had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago. The patient's diabetes is currently managed by his primary care physician, and his glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels had been within the target range for the past year.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient is a married father of three, who worked as a construction worker for over 30 years. He has a sedentary lifestyle, but attempts to walk for 30 minutes, three times a week. The patient consumes a typical Western diet high in fats and carbohydrates. His past medical history was complicated by his recent episode of gastritis caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications used for joint pain due to degenerative joint disease.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Physical examination on admission showed that the patient's serum glucose was 50 mg/dl, and his mental status began improving following two doses of intravenous dextrose administration. His blood pressure was 160/80 mm Hg, and pulmonary exam showed mild wheezing but clear to auscultation.

LABORATORY DATA
Admission lab data is remarkable for potassium of 3.4 mmol/L and hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) of 6.5, confirming good control of his type two diabetes, considering glipizide therapy adjustment two years ago.

HOSPITAL COURSE
The hospital course was remarkable for severe hypoglycemia secondary to glyburide use, with improvement following hospital protocol of correcting the glucose to a value of above 70 mgs, which prevented neurological impairment, allowing patient recovery in three days to normal glucose levels without requiring further insulin intervention to correct for fluctuations caused.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
A 67-year-old retired librarian was admitted to the hospital with a presumed diagnosis of pneumonia. Further evaluation and diagnostic tests were needed to confirm the severity and causative agent of the pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient experienced two days of worsening dyspnea and cough productive of yellowish sputum. The symptoms initially improved with over-the-counter medications but returned and intensified over the past twenty-four hours. Her wife reported a low grade fever, chills, and loss of appetite in the past twelve hours.


PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Her medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, controlled with Synthroid, essential hypertension managed with a calcium-channel blocker, metformin for type two diabetes, and mild intermittent allergic reaction symptoms to pollen for which an antihistamines regimen may be considered.


SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient had been recently vacationing at her family lakehouse with relatives who had some gastrointestinal issues while sharing cooking duties. The patient consumes wine socially two days a week.


PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
During the evaluation on admission, the patient's temperature is 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit with pulse of one hundred fifteen beats per minute and respiratory rate of thirty. Oxygen saturation on room air was eighty eight percent which indicates some degree of hypoxemia and the likely presence of respiratory infection.

LABORATORY DATA
Pertinent lab results revealed a white blood cell count of seventeen point eight thousand per microliter along with radiographic abnormalities indicative of bronchopneumonia.


HOSPITAL COURSE
Patient's management involved intravenous ceftriaxone which has not presented issues despite reported sensitivity to cephalosporin previously which were mild in nature, nonanaphylactic. Given intravenous cefazolin and methylprednisolone and a strict monitoring regimen in order to ensure adequate pain management, prevent allergic reactions and manage fluid status, which were effectively handled during this admission period with an adequate treatment plan adjusted appropriately to prevent reaction from occurring while improving pneumonia related issues significantly, ultimately resulting in discharge from hospital with home based antibiotic course to finish off recovery process ensuring she could get healthy from respiratory afflictions effectively without developing complications and was sent off with clear home based medication regimen plan post hospital admission which went very according to what was desired.

Patient Name: John Thompson  
Age: 47  
Occupation: Construction Worker  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Migraine headache

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 47-year-old male who presented to the emergency room with a chief complaint of severe headache over the past 24 hours. He reported that the headache began suddenly while at work, described as a pulsating sensation predominantly on the right side of his head, accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light. He described the pain as an 8/10 in intensity and noted similar episodes in the past, although none had been as debilitating. Prior self-administered treatments with over-the-counter ibuprofen provided no relief, prompting his visit to the ER.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson has a history of episodic migraines diagnosed two years ago. He manages these primarily with ibuprofen, but has not been consistent with preventive treatments due to fear of medication side effects. He also has a history of hypertension, well-controlled with lisinopril, and was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), for which he takes omeprazole as needed.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John lives with his wife and two children. He has been working full-time in construction for the past 25 years, often exposed to loud noises and bright sunlight at the sites. He reports smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years and occasionally drinks beer on weekends. He denies any illicit drug use. His family history includes his mother having suffered from migraines and his father from hypertension.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Thompson appeared in mild to moderate distress due to pain. Vital signs were remarkable for blood pressure of 150/92 mmHg. Neurological examination showed no focal deficits. Pupils were equal and reactive to light. The fundoscopic examination revealed no papilledema. There was tenderness upon palpation of the right temporalis muscle.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine lab work, including a complete blood count and metabolic panel, were within normal limits. A CT scan of the head performed in the ER showed no acute intracranial process.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with an acute migraine attack. He was administered intravenous fluids, prochlorperazine, and sumatriptan during his ER stay, which significantly reduced his headache intensity from 8/10 to 2/10 over the course of a few hours. He was observed for a short period and discharged later the same day with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician. Mr. Thompson was counseled on the importance of lifestyle modifications, such as reducing caffeine and nicotine use, and considering a migraine-specific preventive medication. He was advised to maintain adequate hydration, avoid known triggers, and use prescribed medications promptly at the onset of headache symptoms. A neurology referral was made for further evaluation of his migraine management and to discuss potential preventive medication options.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Mr. Robert Lambert, a 34-year-old warehouse manager, presented with fever, cough, and shortness of breath. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient was otherwise in his usual state of health until eight days prior to admission when he started experiencing mild fatigue. Four days prior, he developed a persistent cough and fever reaching 39°C. On the day of admission, he noted worsening shortness of breath and decided to seek medical attention. At the emergency room, a chest X-ray revealed a left lower lobe consolidation suggesting pneumonia.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Lambert has a history of asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. He has no history of hospitalizations or surgeries and denies any known allergies. Prior to the current illness, he had not been on any regular medications.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Lambert is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol consumption on social occasions. He is married and lives with his wife and two young children. His occupation involves moderate physical activity. He exercises regularly and follows a balanced diet.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On admission, Mr. Lambert appeared alert but in mild respiratory distress. His temperature was 38.5°C, blood pressure 120/78 mmHg, pulse 102 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 90% on room air. Lung examination revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles at the left lower lung field. Heart sounds were regular with no murmurs. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests showed a white blood cell count of 13,000/mm³ with a left shift. C-reactive protein was elevated. Sputum cultures grew Streptococcus pneumoniae. Blood cultures were pending at the time of admission.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Lambert was admitted for inpatient management of his pneumonia. He was started on intravenous antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and azithromycin, and supplemental oxygen therapy. Over the first two days, his fever subsided, and his respiratory symptoms began to improve. By the third day, the patient's oxygen requirement decreased, and he was weaned off supplemental oxygen. Follow-up blood cultures showed no growth, and inflammatory markers showed a downward trend. On the fourth day of hospitalization, Mr. Lambert was switched to oral antibiotics and continued to show improvement. He was discharged on the fifth day with a prescription for oral antibiotics for an additional seven days and advised to follow up with his primary care physician in one week. He was instructed on recognizing symptoms of worsening respiratory status and the importance of completing the antibiotic course.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The final primary diagnosis for this encounter is osteoarthritis exacerbation, alongside secondary issues related to recent travel and respiratory problems possibly linked to environmental exposure.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
An 87-year-old retired librarian presented to the hospital due to an exacerbation of osteoarthritis symptoms and a recent onset of shortness of breath. She mentioned her difficulty began to escalate three days prior to admission as she struggled with usual activities, such as climbing stairs, without needing to rest more often. There was no chest pain but mild intermittent fever reported throughout these days. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
Throughout her adult life, the patient has managed hypertension with medications that were changed by her primary care physician about six months ago, transitioning from lisinopril to another agent due to a cough. Furthermore, her significant history includes removal of the thyroid gland several decades ago. Her medication list at home includes synthroid to maintain a proper thyroid hormone level and atorvastatin for her diagnosed hyperlipidemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY 
Socially, the patient is active and has been participating in local theater. However, her most recent role required extensive overseas travel last month. Despite her excitement about this opportunity, she reported experiencing stress and some anxiety during the trips. Upon return, besides her arthritic exacerbation and breathing issue, she reported noticing significant fatigue and decreased tolerance for usual daily activities. She denies any illicit substance use but does mention enjoying daily glasses of wine with her meals.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 
A comprehensive physical exam noted diffuse joint inflammation, particularly in her lower limbs and hands, and diminished lung sounds suggestive of restrictive lung disease possibly due to an allergic or viral cause, pending further investigation.

LABORATORY DATA 
Complete blood count showed mild elevation in the white blood cell count suggesting potential infection or other cause for inflammation. Further diagnostic work including high resolution CT scan of chest and possible serologic or exposure assessment would help rule out environmental causes like aspergillosis or histoplasmosis in someone recently traveling abroad.

HOSPITAL COURSE 
Throughout the hospital stay, management included supportive therapies, hydration, oxygen as needed, and adjustments in current therapies including shortterm lowdoses ibuprofen with a proton pump inhibitor to ensure gastrosafety given the potential need to modify or increase medications like prednisone which could have systemic side effects and her already significant history. Close observation during this therapeutic window showed improvement but further assessment is recommended.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Suspected Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mrs. Laura Jenkins, a 62-year-old retired schoolteacher, presented to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of left-side facial droop and slurred speech lasting about 15 minutes. Her symptoms resolved en route to the hospital. She had no previous similar episodes. She did not report any headaches, loss of consciousness, or seizure activity. Her husband, who accompanied her, noted that she appeared confused and had difficulty finding words during the episode.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Her medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago, well-controlled on lisinopril 10 mg daily. She is also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and is currently on atorvastatin 20 mg nightly. She has no history of diabetes, heart disease, or previous strokes. Her surgical history includes a cholecystectomy five years ago. She is up to date on all age-appropriate cancer screenings and vaccinations.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Laura lives with her husband in a suburban area and enjoys gardening and volunteering at the local library. She has a 10-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 15 years ago. She drinks wine socially, consuming approximately one glass once or twice a week. She denies any illicit drug use and has no recent travel history. Her family history is significant for a mother who suffered from a stroke at age 70.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Laura was alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her blood pressure was 140/88 mm Hg, pulse 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations were unremarkable. Neurologic examination revealed no facial asymmetry or speech difficulty, and there was no sensory or motor deficit. Reflexes were symmetric, and her gait was steady.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine blood work, including a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and coagulation profile, was within normal limits. Lipid profile showed total cholesterol of 210 mg/dL, LDL 130 mg/dL, and HDL 50 mg/dL. A non-contrast head CT was performed, which showed no acute intracranial hemorrhage or infarction. An EKG showed normal sinus rhythm.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Laura was admitted for observation and further evaluation. A carotid Doppler ultrasound revealed mild atherosclerotic changes but no significant stenosis. A transthoracic echocardiogram did not reveal any thrombus or cardiac embolic source. Given the clinical picture, she was diagnosed with a transient ischemic attack. She was counseled on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and increased physical activity, to manage her cardiovascular risk factors. Her antihypertensive regimen was optimized, and aspirin 81 mg daily was added for stroke prevention. After 24 hours of observation without recurrence of symptoms, she was deemed stable for discharge with a referral for outpatient follow-up in the stroke prevention clinic. Laura and her husband were educated on the warning signs of stroke and the importance of immediate action should symptoms recur.

Upon hospital admission, the attending physician diagnosed a 75-year-old retired school teacher with community-acquired pneumonia in the ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS section of the file. A detailed review of her medical history through the HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS section showed that her symptoms initiated with a slight cough, which gradually advanced to exhibit high fever, significant respiratory discomfort, and generalized weakness over the period of several weeks.

Her medical background as detailed in the PAST MEDICAL История section showed this patient had well-controlled type two diabetes, documented hypertension, a distant heart attack thirteen years prior that involved an angioplasty. Presently she takes medication daily: two hundred twenty-five milligrams of metformin and forty milligrams of simvastatin and ten milligrams of lisinopril once daily. 

The SOCIAL HISTORY revealed important aspects of her lifestyle: she had been a non-smoker over the course of her lifetime, and she practiced alcohol abstinence, adhering strictly to the tenets of total abstinence, while she led semi-active daily schedules, regularly walking in local recreation parks, maintaining connections of friends with whom she stays in touch regularly.


A detailed general review of all the results of her admission in PHYSICAL EXAMINATION shows signs and symptoms such mild bilateral intercostal retractions with labored deep, rapid breath patterns in line with the presenting admission issue and an increased cardiac rhythm.


On the basis that lab samples collected for the analysis reflected findings such abnormal levels in certain markers consistent, an order for laboratory tests, specifically to confirm presence and assess severity of bacterial infection and check the presence for co-morbidity conditions like cardiac dysfunction through a combination blood tests comprising CBC, CRP, blood electrolytes panel, serum creatinine, chest X-rays for further examination as outlined in laboratory and tests in LABORATORY DATA.

In assessing developments as recorded under hospital course with adjustments in medication regimen according with lab results, our patient experienced mild dysphoric episodes, requiring careful pain management that involved consultation with specialists, monitoring her vitals every shift and follow through of strict intravenous and oral antibiotics for duration until complete recovery of the patient is observed.


Throughout a closely-watched ten-day recovery phase, with regular monitoring and treatment adjustment guided in the context, recovery progression shows overall patient’s general recovery was very steady, which led eventually her discharge in optimal medical condition after ten days following her initial hospital admission.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is an 87 year old retired mechanic who presented to the hospital with acute left lower quadrant pain, radiating to the back, and fever of 38.2 Celsius. The provisional diagnosis at the time of admission was acute pancreatitis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient reported onset of symptoms 24 hours prior to hospitalization, initially experiencing severe epigastric discomfort that gradually shifted to the left lower quadrant. He associated this with a significant increase in his oral intake of fats in recent months as well as the habit of drinking a quart of whiskey every week. Additionally, the family reported recent consumption of undercooked chicken and the patient recalled experiencing watery diarrhea a week prior, which resolved on its own but had a persistent effect on him, likely indicating susceptibility to certain pathogens.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
This 87 year old male has a relevant history of peptic ulcer disease, well managed with famotidine since 2006 after upper endoscopy confirmation and treatment plan implementation. He has type II diabetes under reasonable control and hypertension that's currently managed with losartan. 

SOCIAL HISTORY
He resides with his wife in a home without air conditioning in Arizona, resulting in periods of excessive sweating during extreme outdoor temperatures, exacerbating his blood pressures. Their family also cares for them during hot months to minimize heat-related illness risk, though it has led to changes in dietary plans which the wife feels may be responsible for altering medication responses or increasing symptoms.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Admission Diagnosis:

ADMISSION_DIAGNOSIS
The patient, a 72-year-old retired mechanic, was admitted with a primary diagnosis of acute congestive heart failure, secondary to chronic hypertension and coronary artery disease. 

HISTORY_OF_PRESENT_ILLNESS
The patient presented to the emergency department with a two-day history of worsening dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He reported a recent increase in fluid retention, with significant peripheral edema and fatigue.

PAST_MEDICAL_HISTORY
The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, with two previous myocardial infarctions, and has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. He is also being treated for insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease, stage III. His current medication regimen consists of aspirin, atorvastatin, metformin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and a long-acting insulin analogue. His past medical history also includes mild obstructive lung disease.

SOCIAL_HISTORY
The patient is an avid tobacco user, with over a forty-pack per year consumption, but recently quit smoking six months ago with significant difficulty and nicotine patches to counteract withdrawal symptoms. However, the patient continues to drink two beers daily. He does acknowledge a family history of cardiomyopathy.

PHYSICAL_EXAMINATION
On admission, the physical exam revealed a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, with a respiratory rate of 24.  Lung exam demonstrated scattered wheezes, while the extremities were noted for 1+ pitting edema bilaterally on the right lower leg, with some evidence of skin excoriation, but the left showed no significant alterations.

LABORATORY_DATA
Laboratory results showed mildly deranged renal function, as evidenced by elevated serum creatinine and reduced estimated glomerular filtration rate. Troponin was slightly elevated at 0.03, suggesting possible mild cardiac stress, which might have worsened his clinical presentation of volume overload given an existing heart condition but nothing to conclusively indicate any acute or chronic myocardial infarctor. Hemoglobin A1c levels indicated moderate to poor glucose control of 9.2%. An electrocardiogram confirmed atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. Further investigation is being ordered with the aim to better understand the full impact of his multiple pathologies that might impact our strategy.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Following the results, and in conjunction with cardiology service input, patient care shifted towards improving blood pressures, enhancing fluid balance. Patient will need close management due heart's reduced capabilities alongside potential secondary complications such diabetic management requiring more precise dosages that might involve an immediate diuretic, to address the edema without precipitating severe kidney dysfunction, and close laboratory monitoring in an inpatient basis during hospitalization will continue monitoring patient health throughout treatment progression. Further care adjustments can also help patient cope better during this period alongside a specialist input. Further monitoring and potential additional management is anticipated as treatment strategy progresses, possibly requiring closer examination for potential further complicating disease factors as the heart condition necessitates.

Patient Name: Emily Harper  
Date of Birth: January 15, 1985  
Date of Admission: August 10, 2023  
Date of Discharge: August 15, 2023  

Emily Harper, a 38-year-old female teacher, was admitted with a primary diagnosis of pneumonia.

On August 9, Emily experienced a sudden onset of shortness of breath while at home. She reported feeling unusually fatigued and had a persistent cough. The next day, on August 10, her condition worsened with a high fever and chest pain, leading her to visit the emergency room. Upon evaluation in the ER, a chest X-ray confirmed consolidation in the right lower lobe consistent with pneumonia. She was subsequently admitted to the hospital for further management and observation.

Emily has a significant past medical history of asthma, well-managed with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators, with her last exacerbation occurring a year ago. She also has a history of seasonal allergies and takes over-the-counter antihistamines during the spring months. She denies any other chronic conditions and has no known drug allergies.

In terms of her social history, Emily lives in an urban environment with her husband and two young children. She does not smoke and only occasionally consumes alcohol. She maintains an active lifestyle, regularly engaging in outdoor activities and fitness classes. As a teacher, she spends considerable time around children, which could contribute to increased exposure to respiratory infections. 

On physical examination upon admission, Emily was in mild respiratory distress. Her vital signs were notable for a temperature of 101.8°F, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Auscultation of the chest revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lung base. No wheezing was detected, and the heart sounds were normal.

Laboratory data showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³, C-reactive protein elevated at 85 mg/L, and a sputum culture pending at the time of admission. Arterial blood gases indicated mild hypoxemia.

During her hospital course, Emily was started on intravenous antibiotics, specifically ceftriaxone and azithromycin, to cover both typical and atypical causes of pneumonia. Her asthma medications were continued, and supplemental oxygen was administered to maintain appropriate saturation levels. By the third day of hospitalization, Emily's fever resolved, and her breathing significantly improved. The sputum culture later grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, confirming the diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia.

She responded well to the antibiotic regimen, and her oxygen requirement decreased steadily. She was switched to oral antibiotics on the fourth day and began mobilizing without difficulty.

By August 15, Emily was discharged home in stable condition with instructions to complete a 10-day course of oral antibiotics and follow-up with her primary care physician. She was advised to monitor her respiratory symptoms closely and return to the hospital if she experienced any worsening shortness of breath or recurrent fever. She left the hospital feeling much relieved and grateful for the care received.

Patient Record: 

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Herniated disc L4-L5 with acute exacerbation of low back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Smith is a 34-year-old male construction worker who presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain radiating to the left leg. The pain began two days ago when he was lifting a heavy load at work and has progressively worsened, resulting in difficulty walking and sleeping. He describes the pain as sharp and stabbing, with associated numbness and tingling in the left leg extending to the foot. Prior to this episode, he had been experiencing intermittent back discomfort over the past several months, but never severe enough to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril and episodic migraine headaches for which he occasionally takes over-the-counter ibuprofen. He denies any history of trauma or previous surgical interventions.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John lives with his wife and two young children. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially, limiting his consumption to weekends. He reports no illicit drug use. His work as a construction worker involves frequent heavy lifting and bending. He tries to maintain a healthy lifestyle but admits that his physical activity is primarily work-related rather than scheduled exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient is in moderate distress due to back pain. His vital signs are stable. Neurological examination reveals decreased strength in the left lower extremity, particularly in the dorsiflexors of the foot, with positive straight leg raise test on the left. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the left L5 dermatome. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced at the left Achilles. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar paraspinal muscles.

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits. An MRI of the lumbar spine showed a large herniated disc at the L4-L5 level, compressing the left nerve root.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was started on a regimen of oral steroids and muscle relaxants to alleviate inflammation and muscle spasms. Pain management included a combination of acetaminophen and a low-dose opioid. Despite conservative management, there was minimal improvement in symptoms, and due to the severity of nerve compression, surgical intervention was deemed necessary. He underwent a microdiscectomy to relieve the nerve root impingement. Postoperatively, he experienced immediate relief from leg pain and was mobilized the next day with the help of physical therapy focused on strengthening and flexibility exercises. He was discharged home on the third postoperative day with instructions to avoid heavy lifting and to gradually increase activity as pain allows.

FOLLOWUP VISIT: Two weeks post-surgery, the patient returned for follow-up. He reported significant improvement in back pain and resolution of leg symptoms, with only mild discomfort related to the surgical site. He was advised to continue physical therapy and was cleared to return to light duty work within four to six weeks, with another follow-up appointment scheduled in a month to reassess his progress and potential return to full duty.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 67-year-old former construction worker who was admited with a diagnosis of severe pneumonia. He has been experiencing fever, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort for the past five days.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient stated that his symptoms started with a mild cough and gradually worsened over time. He reported difficulty breathing and an worsening cough over the past week. Prior to admission, he was seen at an urgent care facility where he was given antibiotics, which did not improve his condition. The patient required an increasing amount of supplemental patient controlled oxygen at home to maintain adequate oxygenation, and eventually his daughter brought him to the hospital.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease, for which he has had a previous myocardial infarction. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history of cigarette use and quit four years ago. He currently works part-time, taking care of grandchildren and doing small handyman projects in his free time. He takes atorvastatin, lisinopril, and aspirin for his cardiovascular disease. 

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. The patient lives upstairs in his home with a flight of twenty steps from the living room to the next floor where his bedroom is located. The patient's mobility at the home requires some level of exertion to navigate between spaces.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
A chest exam revealed rales and diminished breath sounds in the left lower lobe of his lung. Cardiac examination revealed a blood pressure equal to elevated ranges with mild pulmonary hypertension in conjunction.

LABORATORY DATA
Upon laboratory testing the patient was noted to have an arterial blood gas revealing moderate hypoxemia, mild anemia on a hemoglobin, and mild thrombocytosis on platelet count tests, indicating likely response due to sepsis with some inflammatory markers mildly decreased.

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient was placed in supplemental patient anesthesia free oxygen with close monitoring, was treated aggressively for pneumonia, with the addition of broad spectrum antibiotic drugs.  Recovery seemed uneventful as patient improved rapidly over a very short period and he was able to tolerate full activity after physical therapy.  Eventually this pneumonia patient made a great full recovery with an expected release home planned on hospital day eight to complete an expected two week course of recovery after hospital discharge is complete. Patient also experienced recovery periods of normal breathing exercises on a regular basis and has continued to work out normally without any discomfort experienced by the patient in breathing post pneumonia event recovery.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 68-year-old male, retired high school teacher, who presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath and productive cough over the past three days. The cough was associated with increased sputum production, which was greenish-yellow in color. The patient reported increased usage of his rescue inhaler but found little relief. He denied any recent travel but noted a significant change in weather, with high humidity over the past week. No fever or chills were reported, but the patient mentioned feeling fatigued and wheezing more often.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of COPD, diagnosed ten years ago, and has been managed with inhalers. He also has hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin, respectively. He has a history of smoking, with a thirty-pack-year history, but quit smoking five years ago. No history of myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives alone in a suburban neighborhood and is independently mobile. Since retiring, he has taken up gardening and enjoys his morning walks. He abstains from alcohol and has no history of illicit drug use. He has a supportive family who visits regularly.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the emergency department, the patient was in mild respiratory distress, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. He was using accessory muscles for breathing. His oxygen saturation on room air was 88%, which improved to 92% with supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Lung auscultation revealed diffuse wheezing and decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Cardiovascular and neurological examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory tests showed a mild leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 12,500/mm³. Electrolyte levels and renal function were within normal limits. A chest X-ray was performed, revealing hyperinflated lungs with no acute infiltrates. Arterial blood gas demonstrated respiratory acidosis with partial compensation.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the respiratory unit for management of COPD exacerbation. He was started on nebulized bronchodilators and a course of oral corticosteroids. A macrolide antibiotic was initiated empirically to cover potential bacterial infection. Throughout the hospital stay, the patient's respiratory status gradually improved. A consultation with the respiratory therapist was made for inhaler technique education and to reassess the long-term treatment plan. By day four, the patient was ambulating comfortably with stable oxygen levels and a significant reduction in cough. He was discharged on day five with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician and the pulmonary clinic for ongoing management and support in preventing future exacerbations.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Past diseases in this geriatric patient include type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, which have been controlled over the years on oral hypoglycemias like metformin alongside ramipril prescribed at an outpatient clinic setting in an area distant from urban sprawl and closer to countryside, for years managed at low and sometimes nil medication, with the patient also taking an oral anticoagulant like acenocoumarol after mechanical valvular heart replacement done abroad 20 years prior to this recent, worrying clinical deterioration presenting at our medical institution this week.

SOCIAL HISTORY
Mr Wilsons home includes smoke alarms which are periodically inspected by his offspring every week who stay about thirty miles west from here with their large household in town comprising of five younger family siblings and other relatives requiring his financial as well as social support through monthly money orders for food.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Our comprehensive head-to-toe medical exam disclosed an underweight elderly male patient laying stationary supine. Noting pallor as also observed under oral hypoglycaemic use and the clinical relevance of an irregular heart rhythm, detected upon cardiac auscultation performed by medical officers from this very ward that further supported the suspicion of possible atrial fibrillation requiring an electrocardiogram to verify initial physical assessments and correlate them.

LABORATORY DATA
The electrocardiogoram performed did confirm a chaotic irregular heart rhythm and in other relevant and appropriate laboratory findings that supported pre-existing diagnosis and further management and the comprehensive geriatric clinical review, also indicated a slight deviation to mild anaemia of possibly chronic type given renal insufficiench with a HbA1 c at ten point eight on initial admission, and serum urea just above three hundred, pointing out for us the underlying pathology for the disease process of his known diabetic and pre existing renal problems with no movement disorders recorded by treating clinicians throughout his in hospital sojourn and stay with our hospital unit this fortnight.

HOSPITAL COURSE
A comprehensive management and rehabilitation programme focusing upon dietary education, medication optimality and stabilising his chronic renal conditions and anaemia with transfusions arranged and planned discharge dates and transfer to rehabilitation care in stepdown facility next week after stabilisation to an acceptable extent on renal drugs with dietician follow-appointments also arranged and booked by care coordinator at our hospital clinic here before planned transfer elsewhere.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 78-year-old retired factory worker who was admitted with a diagnosis of pneumonia. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
He reported a two-day history of cough and fever that began after a hospital visit with his wife, who was undergoing surgical repair of a fractured hip. The patient initially thought his symptoms were just a bad cold but decided to come to the hospital after his cough worsened and he started bringing up yellow sputum.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
His past medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease, and hypertension, for which he takes an ACE inhibitor and a statin. He is also being managed for benign prostatic hyperplasia. He had been experiencing some gastrointestinal discomfort but attributed it to new medication his primary doctor started.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient works part time as a groundskeeper, has a history of moderate smoking, approximately one pack per day, but has been trying hard to stop in recent years. His diet is not very healthy, but recently the home care services started cooking his meals as his physical limitations grew.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
On physical examination, he appeared unwell and was tachypneic, needing oxygen at 4 L/min. His lungs showed inspiratory crackles in both bases. Cardiovascular and other exams did not turn up specific pathology apart from expected chronic low-grade heart conditions seen at this age.

LABORATORY DATA
Blood cultures and urine cultures did not show any signs of sepsis, though the sputum culture revealed presence of gram-positive cocci, consistent with likely streptococcal infection.

HOSPITAL COURSE
On his fifth hospital day, after initiation of antibiotics, there is noticeable clinical improvement, the use of antibiotics seems to clear up respiratory distress significantly faster and now he awaits only further assessment by physical therapy to gauge the full level of functional impairment sustained during prolonged convalescence and hospital stay so an informed disposition plan could made on him when the multidisciplinary rounds convene again tomorrow. Patient also required skin creams to reduce mild peeling on his face after prolonged periods being bed bound that was thought to be exacerbated in some part due to a skin condition he'd struggled in past that leaves large flaky regions when under prolonged periods under fluorescent lighting common in these healthcare settings.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Mitchell, a 58-year-old accountant, presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of chest pain while at work. The pain started approximately 30 minutes prior to arrival and was described as severe, retrosternal, and radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reported associated symptoms of diaphoresis and nausea. Unable to relieve the pain with rest or antacids, his colleagues promptly called for emergency medical services, prompting his transport to the hospital.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Mitchell has a history of hypertension, diagnosed five years ago and well-controlled with lisinopril. He is a former smoker, having quit three years ago after a 20-year history of daily cigarette use. He denies any previous cardiac events and has generally been compliant with his cardiology appointments and advised lifestyle modifications.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Mitchell is married and lives with his spouse. He works full-time as an accountant, often enduring periods of high stress, especially during tax season. He enjoys playing tennis on weekends and adheres to a moderately healthy diet but admits to frequenting fast food more often than recommended. He drinks alcohol occasionally, usually during social events, and denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On arrival, Mr. Mitchell appeared diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg, heart rate at 95 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed no murmurs, but there was noted tachycardia. Lung examination was unremarkable, and there was no peripheral edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, consistent with an inferior myocardial infarction. Cardiac enzymes were notably elevated, with troponin levels significantly above normal limits. Additional laboratory workup indicated mild hyperlipidemia and normal renal function.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Mitchell was promptly diagnosed with a myocardial infarction and was taken for an urgent percutaneous coronary intervention. He underwent successful angioplasty with stenting of the occluded right coronary artery. Post-procedure, he was monitored in the coronary care unit for 48 hours and started on dual antiplatelet therapy, statins, and beta-blockers. His recovery was uneventful, and he experienced no further episodes of chest pain. Upon discharge, he was referred to cardiac rehabilitation and advised to have regular follow-up visits with his cardiologist to monitor his heart health closely and adjust his treatment as necessary.

Mr. Mitchell returned for his first follow-up visit four weeks post-discharge, reporting significant improvement. His adherence to medication and lifestyle changes was noted, and he expressed gratitude for the swift medical intervention he received. Further follow-up visits were planned to ensure continued cardiovascular health and to reassess lifestyle and therapeutic options as needed.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath over the past three days, accompanied by increased cough and sputum production. The patient reported experiencing these symptoms intermittently over the last few months, but they have significantly worsened recently. He denies any chest pain but mentions a recent episode of wheezing and a mild fever. His symptoms were partially relieved by using his home nebulizer treatment, prompting him to seek further medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) diagnosed 10 years ago. He also has hypertension, diagnosed 5 years ago, controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily. He previously was hospitalized for a similar exacerbation of COPD two years ago. No history of coronary artery disease or diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and quit smoking five years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. He has two grown children and a supportive family network.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs indicated a temperature of 101.2°F, pulse 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute, blood pressure 140/85 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation was 88% on room air, improved to 94% with supplemental oxygen. Lung auscultation revealed bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds at the bases. Cardiovascular examination was normal, and no peripheral edema was noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Arterial blood gases demonstrated increased carbon dioxide retention with a pH of 7.35, pCO2 of 56 mmHg, and pO2 of 65 mmHg on room air. Complete blood count showed mild leukocytosis. The chest X-ray revealed hyperinflation of the lungs with no evidence of pneumonia. A spirometry test confirmed severely reduced FEV1 consistent with his known COPD diagnosis.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward for acute management of COPD exacerbation. He was started on bronchodilator therapy with albuterol and ipratropium via nebulization, systemic corticosteroids, and antibiotic coverage with azithromycin to address possible infectious triggers. Supplemental oxygen was provided to maintain oxygen saturation above 90%. Respiratory therapy initiated a program of chest physiotherapy and taught the patient breathing exercises. Over the course of his hospitalization, the patient showed gradual improvement in respiratory status. By the third day, he was able to ambulate with minimal dyspnea and maintained adequate oxygen saturation on 2 liters of oxygen. He was educated on the importance of smoking cessation, consistent use of his medications, and the need for regular follow-ups with his primary care physician. The patient was discharged home in stable condition with a tapering dose of prednisone and instructions to continue his COPD regimen. A follow-up visit with a pulmonologist was scheduled for further management of his chronic lung disease.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The patient is a 78-year-old retired librarian with a diagnosis of acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to her complex medication regimen. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
She initially presented to her primary care physician with complaints of increased fatigue and lower back pain after returning from a solo backpacking trip in Arizona. Her symptoms gradually worsened over the next few weeks, prompting her to make an urgent care visit. Her blood pressure readings were consistently high, prompting the urgent care physician to refer her to our hospital for further evaluation and management.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
She has a long-standing history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis for which she has been managed on multiple medications, including lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and diclofenac. Additionally, she was diagnosed with asthma two years ago and uses her albuterol inhaler as needed.

SOCIAL HISTORY
She lives alone in a two-story home, and her son checks on her regularly. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day until ten years ago when she quit after being diagnosed with mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She also consumes approximately two glasses of red wine every week.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
On physical examination, the patient was noted to be slightly dyspneic, with a blood pressure reading of 170/90 mmHg. A faint expiratory wheeze could be detected bilaterally on lung auscultation, but her pulmonary exam was overall stable considering her COPD history. A 2+ left-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness and slight reduction in lumbar range of motion were consistent with chronic back pain.

LABORATORY DATA
Laboratory studies revealed creatinine elevation to 2.7mg/dL indicating acute kidney injury, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis with an anion gap of 18, and leukocytosis with an absolute neutrophilic count of 13, suggesting an infectious component. Urine analysis and blood culture results are pending.

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient received apheresis therapy for probable hemolytic uremic syndrome which seemed precipitated in her azotemia and possibly contributed further to a significant increase of serum urea nitrogen during therapy as methotrexate treatment likely exacerbated underlying renal disease resulting in increased kidney dysfunction and adverse hemodialysis that contributed to need her hospitalization given significant adverse renal impact.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Coronary Syndrome

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 67-year-old retired school teacher who presented to the emergency room with a 2-hour history of sudden onset chest pain. She described the pain as severe, squeezing in nature, located substernally, and radiating to her left arm and jaw. The onset of the pain occurred while she was doing light gardening. The chest pain was associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. She took 81 mg aspirin at home, which provided no relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She had a left knee arthroplasty three years ago and has been generally in good health otherwise. She is on multiple medications including lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She reports compliance with her medication regimen.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, socially. She lives with her husband and is active in her community, volunteering at the local library. She maintains a relatively healthy lifestyle, walks daily, and maintains a balanced diet, although admits to occasionally indulging in sweets.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, the patient was alert and oriented but appeared in acute distress due to pain. Her blood pressure was 160/95 mm Hg, heart rate 95 beats per minute, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, and she was afebrile. Cardiac examination revealed an irregular heartbeat with no murmurs. Lung fields were clear on auscultation. Extremities were warm with no edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial blood work was notable for an elevated troponin level indicative of myocardial injury. Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits except for a fasting glucose level of 145 mg/dL. Her lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol at 160 mg/dL.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the coronary care unit for further management of Acute Coronary Syndrome. She was started on a heparin drip and received clopidogrel and high-dose atorvastatin. Her symptoms improved significantly with medications. An echocardiogram showed mild left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction. She underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a 90% stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery. A drug-eluting stent was successfully placed.

During her stay, the patient's blood pressure was managed with an increased dose of lisinopril and metformin was continued for her diabetes control. Cardiac rehabilitation was discussed, and she was advised strict adherence to a heart-healthy diet and regular follow-up with her cardiologist. She was discharged home in stable condition after a 3-day hospital stay with arrangements for close outpatient follow-up.
