Bilateral crackles were noted on lung auscultation. There was 2+ bilateral pitting edema up to the knees.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory results showed elevated BNP levels at 800 pg/mL, consistent with heart failure exacerbation. Serum creatinine was 2.0 mg/dL, slightly elevated from the patient’s baseline, indicating possible renal involvement. Electrolytes revealed hyponatremia at 130 mEq/L. A chest X-ray indicated pulmonary congestion and cardiomegaly.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the cardiology service for management of heart failure exacerbation. Diuresis was initiated with intravenous furosemide, leading to significant symptomatic relief and reduction in edema. His fever resolved with supportive care, with blood cultures remaining negative, and a presumptive diagnosis of a viral upper respiratory infection was considered. The patient was closely monitored, and his fluid overload improved. Adjustment of his antihypertensive and heart failure medication regimen was conducted, including the addition of an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor. Discharge planning included referral to cardiac rehabilitation and patient and family education on heart failure management. The patient was stable for discharge on hospital day five, with follow-up appointments scheduled with his cardiologist and nephrologist.

Patient Record:

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient, a 58-year-old male accountant, was admitted after experiencing the sudden onset of chest pain while mowing his lawn on a warm autumn afternoon. The chest pain was described as a heavy, crushing sensation radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reported associated symptoms of dyspnea, nausea, and diaphoresis. After trying to rest with no relief of symptoms, he decided to visit the emergency room, where an initial electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads, alongside elevated cardiac biomarkers, suggestive of an acute coronary event.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 15-pack-year history of smoking, though he quit smoking five years ago. He also has a family history of coronary artery disease, as both his father and two older brothers suffered myocardial infarctions.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is married and lives with his wife. He works as an accountant and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle due to the demands of his job. His diet is high in saturated fats, and he admits to minimal physical activity, mostly on weekends. Despite quitting smoking five years ago, he occasionally drinks alcohol socially.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared diaphoretic and slightly anxious. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg, and a heart rate of 98 bpm. Cardiovascular examination showed normal heart sounds without murmurs, but heart rate irregularities consistent with occasional premature beats. Lungs were clear to auscultation, and no peripheral edema was noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests displayed elevated troponin levels consistent with cardiac muscle damage. Comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, and coagulation profile were within normal limits aside from mild dyslipidemia, with LDL cholesterol elevated at 158 mg/dL.

HOSPITAL COURSE: After admission, the patient was promptly managed for acute coronary syndrome. He was administered antiplatelet therapy and anti-anginal medications, along with a statin. Due to the presentation and severity of symptoms, the cardiology team performed an emergent coronary angiography which revealed a significant proximal occlusion of the right coronary artery. Subsequently, the patient underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with balloon angioplasty and drug-eluting stent placement. Post-procedure, the patient was monitored in the coronary care unit and then transitioned to the cardiology ward for recovery. He was educated on lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and the importance of adherence to cardiac medications. He was discharged on a regimen including aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metoprolol.

FOLLOW-UP VISIT: The patient attended a follow-up clinic visit two weeks post-discharge. He reported adherence to his medication regimen without adverse effects. He had started cardiac rehabilitation, including tailored exercise sessions and diet adjustments. Repeat assessments showed improved blood pressure control, and follow-up lipid panel results indicated better controlled cholesterol levels. Adjustments to his exercise routine were recommended to further enhance his cardiac health and prevent recurrence of symptoms.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Exacerbation of Asthma

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 42-year-old woman who works as a florist and presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness over the past two days. She reported that the symptoms began shortly after starting a new arrangement featuring lilies, which have previously triggered mild respiratory discomfort. She initially attempted relief using her prescribed inhaler but experienced limited success this time, prompting an ER visit.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of asthma diagnosed at age 15, with a few exacerbations requiring emergency care over the years. She also has seasonal allergies, managed with over-the-counter antihistamines, and mild hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril 10 mg daily. She has no history of hospitalizations or surgeries and no known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives with her husband and two teenage children in an urban area. She does not smoke, and consumes alcohol occasionally, averaging one glass of wine on weekends. She exercises occasionally by gardening and walking in her neighborhood. Her family includes a brother with mild asthma and a mother with type 2 diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was alert, speaking in short sentences due to breathlessness. Her respiratory rate was elevated at 24 breaths per minute, and she had nasal flaring and accessory muscle use. Lung auscultation revealed bilateral wheezing, more pronounced on expiration. She was afebrile, with a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count revealed no leukocytosis. The arterial blood gas showed mild hypoxemia with an arterial pH of 7.44, a pCO2 level of 38 mmHg, and a pO2 of 68 mmHg. Spirometry conducted in the ER demonstrated reduced peak expiratory flow rate consistent with asthma exacerbation.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was initiated on nebulized bronchodilators in the ER and continued asthma management using systemic corticosteroids. She improved significantly following this <TREAT:INHALER> therapy and supplemental oxygen. Her symptoms were closely monitored, with notable improvement in her wheezing and ability to engage in full conversation without visible effort. A <FOLLOWUP_VISIT> was scheduled with her primary care physician in one week, with instructions to monitor her trigger exposures more cautiously and a review of her asthma action plan. She was discharged home with clear instructions to continue her inhaled corticosteroids as maintenance therapy and to report any worsening symptoms promptly. The patient expressed understanding of the importance of regular follow-up appointments to manage her asthma effectively.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
Pancytosis with concerns for chronic myeloproliferative disorder versus myeloproliferative neoplasm was diagnosed in an eighty-year-old female retired school teacher, presenting to the emergency department upon advice of primary care for abnormal laboratory findings discovered during evaluation of fatigue.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient reports several weeks of progressive and severe fatigue and weight loss that made daily tasks difficult, necessitating help with managing the household from family members. The primary care provider initially attributed these findings to aging, poor diet, and deconditioning but pursued laboratory evaluations when symptom severity necessitated an ER evaluation. This led to the discovery of abnormal blood work.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Relevant medical conditions include coronary artery disease managed by medications including carvedilol, a prior appendicitis treated surgically at a young age, and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient had smoked a pack and a half per week when her husband developed chronic lung disease but reduced smoking by two-thirds since then and continues with decreased frequency, citing this change as due in part to her husband needing a clean living environment for health improvement purposes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
The initial evaluation at admission revealed a thin female appearing frail, slightly anxious but oriented times four. Vital signs are stable though there does exist pronounced lymphadenopathy and notable hepatosplenomegaly which were further studied in subsequent workup for etiology assessment.

LABORATORY DATA
A CBC with differential showed pancytosis concerning possible myeloproliferative neoplasm but initial peripheral blood film was felt suggestive of leukoerythroblastosis in bone marrow examination misleads to possible interpretation for chronic disease states including possible secondary causes in absence confirmatory studies, in an eighty-year-old female retired teaching staff. The patient had thrombophilic mutations that were noted during workup including Factor V that can increase the clotting tendency as noted through Factor V assay test in her labs which initially may appear not significantly impactful by a physician but when viewed with all patient information provided an interesting insight.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Patient underwent further testing, notably a flow cytometric evaluation alongside the initial findings that provided valuable evidence guiding treatment that may help address her disease state while a review and assessment through imaging were pursued, a notable CT scan showing diffuse lymph node involvement in the context of the previously discovered abnormal lab finding led a radiologist on a misinterpretation by patient regarding diffuse adenopathy, where patient inappropriately interpreted her PET result without considering her diffuse adenitis diagnosis previously and her physician felt patient understanding needed careful clarification with her bone findings being critical information. This necessitated a team of specialist, led by a primary medical care attending working closely, ensuring that her clinical care needs including addressing and alleviating the root concerns and her symptom improvement goals, alongside management by hematologists were fully achieved during this inpatient hospital stay with a view toward optimizing symptom relief measures post-discharge.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute coronary syndrome

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male who works as an accountant. He presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain that began while he was at work. The pain was described as a pressure-like sensation radiating to his left arm and jaw, associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He stated that the symptoms started approximately two hours before admission and have been persistent since. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, which has been poorly controlled despite prescribed antihypertensive medications, including amlodipine and lisinopril. He also has hyperlipidemia but has not consistently taken his statin due to concerns about side effects. No prior history of coronary artery disease was noted. He has a family history of myocardial infarction, with both his father and brother experiencing cardiac events in their early 60s.

SOCIAL HISTORY: He is married, has two adult children, and lives a sedentary lifestyle, given his occupation. He reports occasional alcohol consumption, averaging about four drinks per week, and has a 20-pack-year smoking history, having quit about five years ago. He denies use of recreational drugs.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was alert and oriented but appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg, heart rate was 98 bpm, respiratory rate was 22/min, and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed regular rhythm, but there was a notable S4 gallop. Lung auscultation was clear bilaterally. The remainder of the physical exam was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory results demonstrated elevated cardiac troponins, consistent with acute myocardial infarction. Electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V5, indicating an anterior wall myocardial infarction. Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits, except for mildly elevated LDL cholesterol levels.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. After ER presentation, there was a rapid initiation of treatment with thrombolysis given the timing of chest pain onset and the ST-segment elevation pattern. He responded well to treatment, with a marked reduction in chest pain and stabilization of vital signs. Subsequent follow-up echocardiogram showed moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and a cardiology consult recommended the addition of beta-blockers and high-intensity statin therapy. He was also advised to undergo lifestyle modifications, emphasizing a heart-healthy diet and regular physical activity. Prior to discharge, a follow-up visit with his primary care physician and cardiologist was scheduled to reassess his cardiovascular status and optimize his medical management. The patient was discharged on day three in stable condition.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Respiratory Failure with Hypercapnia

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Fifty-seven-year-old former miner and heavy smoker, Ronald Thompson, presented to the emergency department with increasing somnolence and shortness of breath over several days. His son reported finding multiple empty bottles of oxycontin at home, which the patient has been taking regularly since a recent spinal disc herniation. Family members noticed that over the past month he had been having difficulty waking up in the morning and exhibited noticeable lethargy. They denied any signs of respiratory distress, but noted that the patient sometimes would stop breathing for short periods during his sleep, then start awake again. Prior to admission the patient had been seen in multiple urgent care clinics for symptoms related to the herniated disc.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient is hypertensive and has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with an established diagnosis ten years ago after a particularly bad flare up that landed him in the hospital requiring mechanical ventilation for three days. His most recent hospitalization was for pulmonary rehabilitation following an exacerbation three months prior. Past surgeries include an appendectomy twelve years ago and an unrelated skin graft surgery six months ago. Chronic pain management has become essential, as he relies regularly on tramadol, along with intermittent use of an albuterol inhaler for his obstructive episodes and oxybutynin for urge incontinence stemming from disc compression and subsequent bladder control trouble. The patient's mother had pulmonary disease while his sister was a lung transplant candidate, so familial component may contribute.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Ronald quit smoking five yearsago following a heart attack but continues to live with family members that still smoke at home, and thus remains in an area of passive smoking risks despite personal cessation. His occupational background included thirty three years in deep rock coal mining for which there was exposure documented for coal particles in lung. The patient's wife passed away from breast cancer two years ago. Since, social support is from his children and grandchildren that are trying to manage the patient in home setting when respiratory crisis arise which are increasing.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Mr Thompson appears drowsy, mildly cyanotic with poor respiratory expansion upon chest movements, showing coarse rales over his mid lung fields. Heart examination demonstrated elevated jugular venous distension with clear lung edema noted as a probable result of chronic heart disease progression. Upon review oxygen saturation was thirty nine at presentation necessitating quick oxygen administration to stabilize his declining state.

LABORATORY DATA: ABG results demonstrated respiratory depression type-2 which led him being intubated on mechanical respiratory assistance for stabilization and subsequent transfer to intensive care unit monitoring given severity at time and likelihood it may progress quickly due multiple etiologies likely related chronic medication, possible overdose of the opioid oxycontin coupled his chronic pulmonary condition as well recent past surgeries adding potential risks to pulmonary functionality post op state now.

HOSPITAL COURSE: After several days in ICU and subsequent successful oxygen therapy, and titration off continuous opioids given evidence of opioid related complications respiratory depression with hypercarbia he is now breathing on his own on oxygen supplementation only and beginning participation with pulmonary rehabilitation services, and the consideration of medication assisted treatment of chronic pain management given opioid induced respiratory failures experienced on the higher chronic dosages and the goal now is to ensure that any pain management is done so safely to not trigger respiratory compromise such in the instance witnessed upon his arrival to our acute care service.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute pneumonia superimposed on chronic asthma exacerbation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 56-year-old male software engineer who presented to the emergency room with complaints of worsening shortness of breath, chest tightness, and a productive cough over the past three days. Symptoms began following a recent trip to New York, where the patient attended an outdoor festival, which may have exacerbated his asthma. He also reported low-grade fevers and generalized malaise. There was an ER visit one week ago for similar symptoms, where he was treated with an inhaled bronchodilator and advised to follow up with his primary care physician, but the patient did not attend the scheduled appointment due to work commitments.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Significant for asthma diagnosed at age 30, with previous similar exacerbations occurring seasonally. He has well-controlled hypertension, managed with lisinopril, and hyperlipidemia for which he takes atorvastatin. He had a tonsillectomy in childhood and no history of hospitalizations for respiratory issues.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a nonsmoker who drinks alcohol socially on weekends. He lives in a suburban area with his wife and has two grown children. He denies any illicit drug use. His occupation involves long hours and frequent travel, which occasionally disrupts his sleep and medication routine.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared in mild respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, tachycardic at 112 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 138/86 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Auscultation revealed diffuse wheezing bilaterally with decreased air entry in the right lower lobe. He had rhonchi and dullness to percussion over the same area, suggestive of consolidation.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count showed leukocytosis with a left shift. C-reactive protein was elevated. The chest X-ray indicated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Arterial blood gases showed mild respiratory alkalosis.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward for further management of acute pneumonia and asthma exacerbation. He was started on intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin to cover community-acquired pneumonia. Nebulized bronchodilators were administered every four hours, and a respiratory therapist was involved for chest physiotherapy. Intravenous methylprednisolone was initiated to reduce airway inflammation. Over the course of four days, the patient's symptoms significantly improved; his oxygen requirements decreased and wheezing subsided. He was transitioned to oral prednisone and discharged with instructions for a broad-spectrum inhaler and antibiotics. A pulmonologist follow-up visit was arranged for ongoing asthma management and to reassess lung function in two weeks. The patient was advised on the importance of consistent follow-up to prevent recurrent exacerbations, especially during travel.

Patient Record Summary

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient, a 72-year-old retired school teacher and lifelong resident of a small town, presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath and productive cough over the past week. The sputum was noted to be yellowish, and she reported a low-grade fever for three days. She denied experiencing chest pain, hemoptysis, or sudden onset respiratory distress. Her symptoms initially began two weeks ago with mild rhinorrhea and malaise, which she attributed to a seasonal cold she was exposed to at her great-grandson’s birthday party.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a significant history of COPD, diagnosed eight years ago due to a long history of smoking, which she quit five years ago. She also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medication regimen includes a daily inhaled corticosteroid (budesonide/formoterol), lisinopril 10 mg once daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg at bedtime. She has no history of ischemic heart disease or diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives with her daughter and son-in-law and is highly involved in the family dynamics, often aiding in the daily care of her grandchildren. She is a widow and stopped smoking five years ago after smoking approximately one pack per day for over 40 years. She consumes alcohol occasionally, primarily during social events, and does not use illicit drugs. She walks daily in her neighborhood as a form of exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient was found to be in mild respiratory distress, with an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Physical exam revealed diffuse bilateral wheezing on auscultation of her chest, and her respiratory rate was elevated at 24 breaths per minute. She had a heart rate of 88 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 136/82 mmHg. She was afebrile on assessment in the ER.

LABORATORY DATA: The complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a white cell count of 13,500 cells/mcL, indicating a possible infection. A comprehensive metabolic panel was largely unremarkable. Sputum cultures and sensitivity testing are pending. A chest radiograph revealed hyperinflation consistent with COPD and increased bronchovascular markings suggestive of a possible superimposed infection without overt consolidation.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the respiratory ward and commenced on supplemental oxygen therapy. She was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics (amoxicillin/clavulanate) and received nebulized bronchodilators (albuterol/ipratropium) every four hours, along with continued use of her inhaled corticosteroids. During her hospital stay, her respiratory symptoms improved significantly, and her oxygen requirements reduced back to her baseline of room air after 48 hours. The culture results confirmed a bacterial infection, responsive to the prescribed antibiotic therapy. She demonstrated increased exercise tolerance, walking unassisted for short distances around the ward. Comprehensive discharge planning included smoking cessation reinforcement despite her quit status, respiratory physiotherapy exercises, and a follow-up visit with her pulmonologist in four weeks for a reassessment. Her discharge medication regimen was adjusted to include a five-day course of prednisolone to prevent further exacerbations. The patient expressed gratitude towards the healthcare team and felt confident in managing her conditions at home after hospital discharge.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient, a 55-year-old male carpenter, was admitted to the hospital with the diagnosis of acute radiation syndrome after completing a course of radiation therapy for prostate cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Two days after finishing his final radiation treatment, the patient began experiencing fatigue, diarrhea, and pain on his lower back. He initially believed these symptoms to be a transient adverse effect of radiation, however, the severity worsened progressively, eventually necessitating him to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has a significant past medical history that includes prostate cancer diagnosed two years ago, hypertension managed through lifestyle modification and enalapril, high cholesterol treated with simvastatin, and chronic pancreatitis for which he follows a low-fat diet and takes lipase replacement therapy. In addition to these, he is a heavy smoker and has tried multiple times, however unsuccessful in quitting.

SOCIAL HISTORY
A retired carpenter turned carpentry instructor at a local vocational school, this middle-aged patient lives with his wife. Apart from a pack a day smoking habit he started more than three decades ago and social alcohol consumption of up to two standard drinks every weekend, his life-style otherwise remains largely conventional. Both parents and siblings in his immediate and close lineage succumbing largely due cancer.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
During assessment on admission the patient shows multiple radiation burns, evident as tender erythema localized on skin over his sacrum posteriorly extending to gluteal cleft region secondary possibly an incorrect positioning throughout prolonged radiation treatments.

LABORATORY DATA
Full complete tests ordered including CBC reveal neutropenia alongside decreased levels of hemoglobin thus prompting further assessment of possible infection complications, though preliminary urinalysis indicates nothing outside normal. Liver function enzymes remained stable and no sign suggestive pancreatic insufficiency.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Given his admission diagnosis, an appropriate treatment protocol commenced comprising wound dressing and antibiotics covering possibility skin infection following radiation burn as identified upon physical evaluation and lab analysis respectively. Pain associated managed through standard medication for symptom relief while arrangements made facilitate a followup visit the department oncology evaluate for probable further management related adverse sideeffects of therapy to patient and to further investigate underlying causative factors radiation burns on skin after radiation therapy the patient underwent.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 68-year-old retired schoolteacher who presented to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening cough, fever, and dyspnea. The cough was initially dry but became productive of yellow sputum two days prior to admission. The patient reported feeling generally fatigued and slightly confused over the past 24 hours, prompting her daughter to bring her to the hospital. No chest pain was reported, and there were no recent travel histories.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, managed with lisinopril, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, controlled with metformin. She underwent a knee replacement five years ago and has no history of smoking or alcohol use. She takes atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There is no significant family history of respiratory illnesses.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is widowed and lives alone in a suburban area. She is active in her local community choir and spends time gardening. Her daughter, who visits regularly, assists her with grocery shopping and other chores. She has a supportive network of neighbors and friends from the church.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared moderately ill with labored breathing. Her vital signs revealed a temperature of 102.3°F, blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg, and heart rate of 112 beats per minute. Respiratory rate was 28 breaths per minute with 89% oxygen saturation on room air, which improved to 94% with supplemental oxygen. Lung auscultation revealed crackles in the right lower lobe. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory investigations revealed a white blood cell count of 14,000/mcL with neutrophilic predominance, elevated C-reactive protein, and elevated blood glucose levels suitable for her diabetes history. A chest X-ray demonstrated consolidation in the right lower lobe, consistent with pneumonia. Blood cultures were obtained, and the patient was started on broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics.

HOSPITAL COURSE: During her hospital stay, the patient responded well to antibiotic therapy and supportive care, including oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids. A repeat chest X-ray after 72 hours showed partial resolution of the pneumonia, and her symptoms gradually improved, including a reduction in fever and cough frequency. Blood cultures eventually grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, sensitive to the antibiotics administered. The patient's blood glucose was managed with sliding scale insulin, and she was educated about dietary measures.

On her fifth day of hospitalization, the patient exhibited significant overall improvement. Her oxygen was weaned, and she was able to ambulate around the ward without difficulty. Discharge planning was initiated, including arrangements for continued oral antibiotics for an additional week and follow-up with her primary care physician. Recommendations were made for pneumonia vaccination and diabetes management to prevent future episodes. The patient was discharged home with her daughter and given detailed instructions on medication adherence and symptom monitoring.

Patient Name: Josephine Larson    
Age: 47    
Occupation: High School Teacher    

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS:  
Acute onset of right-sided weakness with slurred speech.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  
Josephine Larson, a 47-year-old female high school teacher, presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of weakness on her right side and slurred speech, which started approximately two hours prior to arrival. She was grading papers at home when symptoms began. Her husband called EMS immediately.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
Josephine has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both of which are controlled with medication. She has no history of diabetes or prior cerebrovascular accidents. She also has seasonal allergies, requiring occasional use of antihistamines.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  
Josephine is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially, approximately once a month. She lives with her husband and two teenage children. She enjoys hiking and participates in a local community theater. There is no family history of stroke or other cardiovascular diseases.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  
Upon examination, the patient was alert but had clear difficulties with articulation. Neurological examination revealed 3/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities, reduced sensation on the right side, and right facial droop. Blood pressure was elevated at 168/92 mmHg. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs.

LABORATORY DATA:  
Initial laboratory tests, including complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, were within normal limits. Lipid panel showed elevated cholesterol levels. Coagulation studies were normal. A CT scan of the head showed no signs of bleeding; however, an MRI revealed an area of ischemia in the left parietal cortex, indicative of an acute infarct.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  
Josephine was admitted to the stroke unit for further management. Due to the timing of her arrival, the decision was made to initiate thrombolysis treatment with tPA. The treatment was well-tolerated without any complications such as bleeding. Blood pressure was closely monitored and controlled using a calcium channel blocker. Over the following days, Josephine began physical and speech therapy. Neurological assessment showed gradual improvement in her motor and speech functions. She was counseled on the importance of strict control of her blood pressure and lipid levels to prevent future events. She was discharged on the sixth hospital day with a recovery plan that included antihypertensive medication adjustments, continuation of statins, a tailored rehabilitation program, and lifestyle modifications to include a heart-healthy diet and increased physical activity. A follow-up visit with her primary care physician and a neurologist was scheduled for two weeks after discharge to assess her progress and adjust her treatment plan as necessary.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute diverticulitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mary Wallis, a 52-year-old school teacher, with no significant prior history of gastrointestinal issues, was admitted with severe left lower quadrant abdominal pain that began two days ago. She described the pain as sharp, constant, and accompanied by nausea, bloating, and low-grade fever. Prior to the onset of pain, Mary had experienced changes in her bowel habits, alternating between constipation and diarrhea for several months, which she attributed to dietary changes. With pain unrelieved by over-the-counter medications and worsening symptoms, she presented to the emergency department for further evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Apart from a history of seasonal allergies and mild hypertension well-controlled with lisinopril, Mary has been otherwise healthy. Surgical history includes an appendectomy at age 18. She has no known history of diabetes or cardiovascular disease.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mary is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol, primarily wine on weekends. She is married, has two teenage children, and enjoys a moderately active lifestyle, engaging in yoga and weekend hikes. Her diet is relatively balanced, although she admits to indulging in high-fiber supplements recently in an attempt to manage her bowel irregularities.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, Mary appeared mildly distressed by pain, with vital signs noting low-grade fever of 100.4°F. Abdominal examination revealed significant tenderness in the left lower quadrant with localized guarding. There was no rebound tenderness, but bowel sounds were decreased.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial blood work revealed a white blood cell count of 13,500/mm³, indicating possible infection, and a hemoglobin level of 13.5 g/dL. Electrolytes and renal function were within normal limits. An abdominal CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of acute diverticulitis, showing thickening of the sigmoid colon with surrounding fat stranding, but no evidence of perforation or abscess.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mary was admitted to the medical ward for conservative management of uncomplicated diverticulitis. Intravenous fluids and antibiotics were initiated, including ciprofloxacin and metronidazole, to cover both aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Pain was managed with acetaminophen as needed, avoiding non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs to minimize gastrointestinal irritation. Mary was educated on dietary modifications, emphasizing a gradual transition to a high-fiber diet to prevent recurrences. Over the next 48 hours, her symptoms improved significantly, with resolution of abdominal pain and normalization of her white blood cell count. She was discharged on day three with a prescription for oral antibiotics and instructions to follow up with her primary care physician in one week for reassessment. Additionally, Mary was referred to a nutritionist for guidance on a sustainable dietary plan aimed at supporting digestive health and preventing future episodes.

Admission Diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of COPD

History of Present Illness: Mrs. Eleanor Greenwood, a 72-year-old retired school teacher with a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), was brought to the emergency room by her daughter due to progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past three days. She reported increased sputum production, which was thick and yellowish, and had started experiencing a persistent cough. Despite using her prescribed bronchodilator inhaler more frequently, her symptoms did not improve. Additionally, her daughter noticed that Mrs. Greenwood was more fatigued than usual and had difficulty performing her daily activities.

Past Medical History: Mrs. Greenwood has a long-standing history of COPD, diagnosed approximately 10 years ago. She also has hypertension, controlled on lisinopril, and osteoarthritis, for which she occasionally takes ibuprofen. She is a former smoker, having quit 15 years ago after smoking one pack per day for 40 years.

Social History: Mrs. Greenwood lives alone in a small apartment and is independent in her activities of daily living. She is widowed and has two grown children who live nearby and assist with shopping and heavy chores. She enjoys reading and gardening but has been unable to tend to her plants due to her recent exacerbation. She consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.

Physical Examination: On examination, her vital signs showed tachycardia and tachypnea, with an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds, more pronounced in the right lower lobe. There was no evidence of peripheral edema.

Laboratory Data: Blood tests showed mild leukocytosis. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed mild respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia. Sputum culture was collected and pending results at the time of this report. Chest X-ray demonstrated hyperinflated lungs with evidence of an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, suggestive of an infectious process.

Hospital Course: Mrs. Greenwood was admitted to the hospital for acute management of her COPD exacerbation. She was placed on supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated to target possible bacterial infection, and she was started on systemic corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation. Nebulized bronchodilators were administered every four hours to alleviate bronchospasm.

Over the course of her hospital stay, Mrs. Greenwood showed gradual improvement in her respiratory status. Her oxygen saturation levels stabilized with decreased supplemental oxygen requirements, and her cough diminished significantly. Physical therapy was consulted to assist with pulmonary rehabilitation exercises to improve her exercise tolerance.

By the fifth day, Mrs. Greenwood was ambulating independently in the hallway without shortness of breath. She was successfully weaned off supplemental oxygen and transitioned to her home regimen of inhalers. After appropriate discharge planning and education on her COPD management plan, Mrs. Greenwood was discharged home with follow-up scheduled with her primary care physician and a pulmonologist.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient, a 76-year-old retired electrician, was admitted to the hospital with a presumed diagnosis of pacemaker lead failure. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of intermittent lightheadedness and dyspnea, which began one week prior to admission. These issues significantly impact his ability to maintain his usual activity level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient experienced a worsening Shortness of breath that worsens significantly when lying down over the previous two weeks. This discomfort compelled him to seek immediate medical assistance at a walk-in clinic near home and later a definitive care center. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Notably the patient experienced cardiac pacemaker implantation twelve years earlier for complete heart block and subsequently suffered coronary artery disease treated by two-vessel coronary artery bypass graft three years subsequent, as revealed by hospital files obtained following patient signing consent forms. Medications prior to hospitalization are 50mg of beta-blocking tablet each morning along with bloodthinning tablet given at an undefined but steady, single time per day under his attending cardiologist prescription, and 20-25mm Hg inhalation therapy, both to manage and prevent worsening condition related to aforementioned heart and lung conditions.


SOCIAL HISTORY
Regarding occupation and related factors, in his most previous line of work, the patient worked long hours daily often on his feet, which likely may have influenced the health issues at an onset that may well have gone clinically unnoticed. He currently lives with and is helped and supported in his day to tasks including reminders in administering medications and grocery purchases and food prep activities by an active 45 year old daughter.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
A focused Physical examination found diminished first heart sound, otherwise unremarkable findings but noted low blood pressure values during the assessment. Noting the clinical relevance a twelve-lead electrogram revealed intermittent failure to stimulate a paced depolarization during lead pacing. 

LABORATORY DATA
Results from blood tests were largely normal. There was found to be an elevated d-Dimer but this value did eventually decrease following several serial measures taken throughout subsequent several  in hospital stay days while a full lab panel returned with the patient showing slightly depressed but nonetheless still normal complete blood and basic metabolic profile throughout inpatient observation, as expected in context.



HOSPITAL COURSE
Hospitalization led to successful identification of lead failure for a permanent single-chamber pacemaker and its resultant intermittent pacing dysfunction through thorough diagnostic and clinical workup as the precipitant cause of the above described presentation which in turn enabled its scheduled operative revision to dual-chamber device, which has function well immediately upon the first use post-replacement and continued upon dismissal home to patient where follow medical supervision to prevent the recurrence and allow adequate, unencumbered activity will necessarily continue post-pacemaker repair revision procedure at home under strict post hospital treatment plan devised pre-discharge from inhouse care physician, as would be in typical hospital treatment post-procedure plan implementation

The patient had hypertension for twelve years diabetes for sixteen years hypercholesterolemia for twenty years coronary artery bypass surgery eight years ago and has experienced multiple episodes of decompensation requiring admission.
