Admission diagnosis is chronic bronchitis exacerbation in a 65-year-old retiree. The patient presented to the emergency department with complaint of worsening shortness of breath and increasing fatigue over the past two weeks. The history of present illness is significant for symptoms of wheezing and cough productive of yellow sputum. The patient reported recently taking a flight, which may have exacerbated symptoms.

Past medical history is significant for asthma, hypertension, and remote history of tobacco abuse. The patient quit smoking twenty years ago and has remained tobacco-free since. Social history is notable for being a lifelong nonsingular woman, never married with four children. Her children often help with cooking, and the patient eats a balanced diet, avoiding excessive processed or high-sodium foods.

The patient also has an active lifestyle and participates in daily thirty-minute brisk walks around her neighborhood when symptoms permit, under guidance of the pulmonology and physical therapy, the sixty-five-year-old female patient received a series rehabilitation exercises focused toward relieving injury to lung tissue that resulted and progressed into the chronic phase exacerbation that we encountered, which is essential in facilitating improvement in respiratory capacity.

Physical examination found the patient in moderate respiratory distress, demonstrating labored breathing with inspiratory and expiratory wheezing throughout both lung fields. The laboratory data show evidence of inflammation in elevated markers from arterial blood gas samples obtained at admission that demonstrate mild acidosis and oxygen desaturation, also a peak flow meter reading was sixty percent capacity from prior baseline assessments recorded previously during less symptomatic period.


 During hospital course it was necessary to administer inhaled corticosteroids by meter-dosed inhalers that are a vital therapy aimed at managing symptoms and decreasing airway inflammation in chronic exacerbations such that the physical therapy could effectively manage injury through respiratory exercises focused at strengthening patient lung functions as demonstrated through physical therapy interventions aimed at improving injury to the lung resulting from disease through evidence showing marked improvement from admission, peak expiratory flow returned towards baseline as wheeze resolved with clearing of lung inflammation from aggressive use pharmaceutical treatment regimen. With improved mobility noted upon daily reassessments and follow up evaluations conducted in line with medical treatment protocols, patient progressed well with the intensive treatment approach that incorporated comprehensive management.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 47-year-old male, Mr. William Sanders, who presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of worsening cough, productive of green sputum, and fever with temperatures ranging from 101°F to 102°F. He also reported shortness of breath, especially upon exertion, and a general feeling of fatigue. Mr. Sanders noted that his symptoms started after returning from a business trip to Chicago. He initially tried over-the-counter medications, which provided no relief, prompting him to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Sanders has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both managed with lifestyle modifications and medication. There is no history of diabetes, asthma, or COPD. He is compliant with his medications, which include lisinopril and atorvastatin. There is no significant surgical history, and Mr. Sanders has no known allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Sanders is a software engineer who lives in a suburban area with his wife and two teenage children. He is a former smoker, having quit ten years ago after a five-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially, averaging 3-4 drinks per week. He exercises regularly, enjoys hiking, and has no history of illicit drug use. There is no significant family history of chronic respiratory illnesses.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: During the initial exam, Mr. Sanders appeared moderately ill, with an elevated temperature of 101.8°F. Respiratory examination revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lung field. His heart rate was elevated at 98 beats per minute, and his blood pressure was stable at 130/78 mmHg. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable, with no peripheral edema or jugular venous distension.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm³ with a left shift. A chest X-ray revealed a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Blood cultures and sputum samples were obtained for microbiological analysis. Arterial blood gases showed mild hypoxemia, and routine metabolic panels were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Sanders was admitted to the general medical floor for further management of community-acquired pneumonia. He was started on intravenous antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and azithromycin. He received supplemental oxygen through a nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation above 92%. Over the first 48 hours, his fever subsided, and his sputum production decreased. Serial blood cultures remained negative, and his white cell count normalized. The infectious disease team recommended continuing oral antibiotics upon discharge.

By the fifth day of hospitalization, Mr. Sanders demonstrated significant clinical improvement. He was transitioned to oral medications, instructed on the importance of complete antibiotic course adherence, and educated about pneumonia prevention strategies, including vaccination. He was discharged on day six with close outpatient follow-up arranged with his primary care physician. Upon follow-up one week later, Mr. Sanders reported full resolution of his symptoms.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 68-year-old retired carpenter who presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of progressive shortness of breath and productive cough. The cough was producing greenish sputum. The patient experienced their first episode of sudden onset dyspnea while at home, prompting an ER visit due to worsening symptoms and an inability to find relief with his home nebulizer treatments.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a long history of COPD, for which he uses a combination of inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. His medical records indicate a past history of hypertension, well-controlled with lisinopril, and hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year history, having quit smoking 10 years ago upon diagnosis of COPD. He has had multiple hospital admissions in the past for COPD exacerbations and has also been treated for pneumonia two years ago.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives alone after the recent passing of his spouse. He remains active in his local church and occasionally volunteers at a community woodworking project for youths. He reports no alcohol use and denies any illicit drug use. His primary caregiver is his eldest daughter, who visits him weekly.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared in slight respiratory distress. Vital signs showed tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation was 89% on room air, improving to 95% with supplemental oxygen. Auscultation of the lungs revealed bilateral wheezing and crackles in the right lower lobe. Other systems appeared unremarkable except for an elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests demonstrated an elevated white blood cell count of 14,000/mm³, suggestive of acute infection. Blood gases indicated partial respiratory compensation with a mild respiratory acidosis. A chest X-ray confirmed the presence of a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Sputum cultures were obtained for further analysis.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward and started on intravenous antibiotics targeting community-acquired pneumonia. His usual COPD regimen with inhaled bronchodilators was continued and adjusted. Over the course of several days, the patient's respiratory function improved significantly. Physical therapy was consulted to assist with ambulation and breathing exercises. By day five of hospitalization, the patient demonstrated marked improvement in symptoms, oxygen requirements were reduced, and he was transitioned to oral antibiotics. Discharge planning included detailed education on COPD management and pneumonia prevention, optimization of his home nebulizer therapy, and arrangements for follow-up with his pulmonologist within one week.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The patient, a 68-year-old former accountant with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, was admitted to the hospital with severe chest pain that radiated to the left arm and jaw, initially suggesting an acute coronary syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The chest pain first began two days prior to admission, but had intensified that morning. The onset was described as sharp and stabbing. He denied experiencing any symptoms following the initial bout until the morning the pain significantly increased.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
His medical history is also significant for a previous bout of gastritis, for which he has been taking omeprazole for several years. Recently, a physician assistant added atorvastatin due to an elevated LDL. Additionally, this elderly gentleman reported undergoing an appendectomy when he was in his late teenage years, without complications. He admitted to a smoking history but quit nearly 7 years ago and now only rarely smokes during stressful periods in social settings, typically when visiting his in-laws or close friends at gatherings.

SOCIAL HISTORY 
Socially, he remains fairly active despite having retired four years ago from accounting. He volunteers as an art conservator for the city historical society museum one afternoon per week and often uses his remaining free afternoons practicing his long-established oil landscapes paintings as leisure activities.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 
On admission, a thorough physical assessment including vital signs showed the patient in obvious distress. However, his airway and mental assessment seemed normal with some heightened level of stress possibly caused from anticipation or reaction to hospital settings or even potential news received during admission regarding his family member's medical status, but nothing more abnormal could initially account.

LABORATORY DATA 
Lab results from that same early morning showed abnormal results in troponin T, confirming initial thoughts and supporting a diagnosis possibly involving myocardial necrosis which might require interventions in line possibly preventing or minimizing infarct.

HOSPITAL COURSE 
Treatment included the implementation of a beta-blocker to control his elevated blood pressure upon discovery and further diagnostic tests including several electrocardiograms in quick series which supported evidence of some transient changes within different time sequences of testing as the treatment progressed to help relieve strain and lower pressures placed in these cardiovascular components while under intense observations closely. Throughout his inpatient admissions, our patient experienced relief from this treatment that was tailored towards him specifically, taking into full context all factors discussed from previous and new data being obtained.

Mrs Garcia, a seventy-two year old retired teacher was diagnosed with atraumatic vertebral body compression fracture upon discharge. Her history of present illness began two weeks prior to admission, when she experienced mild back pain that radiated to the flank, worsened by deep inspiration or any jarring movement. The patient took over the counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications but the intensity of the ache prompted further evaluation by an orthopedist two days later resulting in admission. Upon evaluation a past medical history consisting of well controlled atrial fibrillation on antithrombotic warfarin therapy for stroke prevention was notable. Also significant to her case her lifelong history of nicotine dependence until quitting thirteen years ago.

Notable to her treatment the forty five pack years of smoke likely contributed a considerable health compromise. Her past occupational history entailed physical inactivity. Mrs Garcia consumes red wine occasionally, one or two times a month, does enjoy long walks but is inactive. 

In hospital, her physical examination consisted of a complete examination including tenderness on palpation and percussion of the tenth thoracic vertebral region with notable bruising and decreased breath sounds at lung bases possibly related to deep venous thrombosis given long term enoxaparin and her lifelong blood thinner usage of warfarin, leading to excessive and frequent bleeding episodes requiring transfusion.

She showed abnormalities such as prothrombin times greater than four point fifty which further explained an instance of easy and excessive bruising as seen on multiple occasions including a notable forearm bruise from bumping into a doorway. Laboratory results also indicated renal function alterations. 
 Mrs Garcia began physical and supportive rehabilitative care with gradual improvement noted throughout the duration of her hospital stay and transition to a local inpatient care for follow-up therapy. Despite experiencing multiple falls due her current blood thinner regime causing excessive bruising and bleeding her health improved with the management of pain.

Patient Name: Jacob Harrison  
Age: 47  
Occupation: Middle School Teacher

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS:
Acute Appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Jacob Harrison, a 47-year-old middle school teacher, presented to the emergency room with a five-hour history of worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain. He described the pain as sharp and persistent, initially peri-umbilical but later localized to the right lower quadrant. His symptoms were accompanied by nausea, but he denied any vomiting or fever. Over-the-counter pain medications provided no relief. Concerned about the escalation of his symptoms, he decided to visit the emergency room for further evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Mr. Harrison has a history of hypertension, for which he takes Lisinopril 10 mg once daily. He also has seasonal allergies, managed with over-the-counter antihistamines. Surgical history includes a tonsillectomy during childhood. He is up-to-date with his vaccinations and has no known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Mr. Harrison is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, typically during social events. He lives with his wife and two children in a suburban neighborhood. He enjoys running and participates in local marathons. Diet consists mainly of home-cooked meals, with an emphasis on vegetables and lean protein. He denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
On examination, Mr. Harrison appeared in mild distress due to pain. Vital signs were notable for mild tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 bpm; otherwise, he was afebrile with normal blood pressure. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding and rebound tenderness. Positive Rovsing's sign was noted.

LABORATORY DATA:
Laboratory tests showed a mild leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 12,500/mm³. Other blood tests, including renal function, liver enzymes, and electrolytes, were within normal limits. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed the diagnosis of acute appendicitis with no evidence of perforation.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Given the findings of the CT scan and clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis, Mr. Harrison was admitted for surgery under the care of the general surgery team. He underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy without complications. Post-operatively, he was managed with intravenous fluids and pain control. His recovery was uneventful, with gradual advancement of diet. He was discharged home on post-operative day two with instructions for wound care and a prescription for oral antibiotics and analgesics.

At his follow-up visit one week later, Mr. Harrison reported significant improvement and minimal discomfort at the surgical site. He was advised to avoid heavy lifting for the next four weeks and to gradually resume his usual activities. He was scheduled for another follow-up in three months to ensure complete recovery and management of his hypertension.

Patient Record Summary:

Admission Diagnosis: Acute Myocardial Infarction

History of Present Illness: The patient is a 58-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain while at work as a construction manager. The chest pain started approximately two hours prior to arrival and was described as a severe, crushing sensation radiating to the left arm. He also experienced shortness of breath and dizziness. He tried resting and taking his prescribed nitroglycerin with no relief, prompting the ER visit. 

Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past seven years. He is a non-smoker but has a family history of coronary artery disease, with both his father and older brother having passed away from heart attacks in their fifties. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin, which he has been compliant with.

Social History: The patient is married and has two adult children. He reports moderate alcohol use, typically enjoying a couple of drinks over the weekend. His diet is not strictly controlled, often consuming fast food given his busy work schedule. Although he leads an active lifestyle at his job, he rarely engages in structured exercise.

Physical Examination: On examination, the patient appeared visibly distressed and was diaphoretic. Blood pressure was elevated at 160/95 mmHg, heart rate was 110 beats per minute, and he was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24. Cardiac examination revealed no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, but he had decreased breath sounds bilaterally. 

Laboratory Data: Initial lab work showed elevated cardiac troponins, confirming myocardial injury. The chest X-ray was unremarkable, while the EKG revealed significant ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads, consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

Hospital Course: The patient was promptly started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, alongside high-dose statins as part of the initial management of an acute myocardial infarction. He was taken urgently to the cardiac catheterization lab, where a 90% stenosis of the proximal LAD was identified and successfully treated with a drug-eluting stent. He was monitored in the coronary care unit for 48 hours post-procedure with continuous telemetry. During his stay, diabetes management was optimized with revisions in his metformin dosing, and lifestyle modifications were discussed in detail. He was educated about the importance of adhering to his medication regimen, including statins, to prevent further cardiovascular events.

Follow-Up: The patient was discharged on day four with an outpatient cardiology follow-up scheduled for two weeks post-discharge to monitor his recovery and adjust his medications as needed. He was advised to enroll in a cardiac rehabilitation program and lifestyle counseling for better management of his diet and exercise habits.

Patient Record

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of asthma.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient, a 42-year-old Caucasian male named Thomas Bennett, presented to the emergency department following a sudden onset of shortness of breath. He described experiencing increased difficulty breathing over the past two days, accompanied by a tight sensation in his chest and wheezing. The symptoms were not relieved by his home inhaler use, prompting the visit to the emergency room. He reported no recent respiratory infections but mentioned that symptoms often worsened during the spring season.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Thomas has a known history of asthma since childhood, which had been well managed with an as-needed albuterol inhaler. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago and is currently on lisinopril. Additionally, he has a history of seasonal allergies, primarily in the spring and fall, for which he occasionally takes over-the-counter antihistamines.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Thomas works as a high school math teacher and lives with his wife and two children in a suburban area. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, mainly during social gatherings. He engages in moderate physical activity, including cycling on weekends. He reports no recent travel and adheres to a generally balanced diet, although he notes an increase in fast food consumption recently due to a busy schedule.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Thomas appeared in mild respiratory distress, with nasal flaring and the use of accessory muscles. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 134/86 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Lungs were noted to have bilateral wheezing throughout, more pronounced on expiration. Otherwise, the cardiovascular and abdominal exams were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits. A chest X-ray was performed to rule out any lung infection or pneumothorax, which showed no acute infiltrates. Peak expiratory flow rate was reduced at 200 L/min (normal for his demographic being 600 L/min), confirming an asthmatic exacerbation.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Thomas was administered a bronchodilator nebulizer treatment in the emergency room, which significantly improved his breathing comfort and increased his peak flow readings to 350 L/min. Given the severity of his symptoms and incomplete relief with home management, he was commenced on a short course of oral corticosteroids. After stabilization, he was discharged with instructions for oral prednisone for five days, in addition to continuing his albuterol inhaler. Referral for a follow-up visit was made to his primary care provider to reassess his asthma management plan, with a focus on implementing a preventer inhaler to better control his symptoms and avoid future exacerbations. Thomas left the hospital in a stable condition, understanding the importance of adherence to his treatment and follow-up care.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute pyelonephritis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 45-year-old female teacher who presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of progressively worsening left flank pain, fever, and dysuria. She reported chills and a fever reaching 102°F, along with nausea but no vomiting. She did not initially seek medical attention, hoping the symptoms would resolve. Her urine output had decreased despite trying to increase her fluid intake.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, managed with amlodipine for the last five years, and type 2 diabetes, controlled with metformin. She had a cholecystectomy two years ago but otherwise has no significant surgical history. She is regularly followed by her primary care physician for her chronic conditions.

SOCIAL HISTORY: She lives with her husband and two teenage children in an urban area. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally, usually socially during weekends. She exercises intermittently, mainly walking her dog in the evenings. She maintains a balanced diet, though admits to consuming sugary snacks occasionally, which she is attempting to minimize given her diabetic status.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared ill and in mild distress due to pain. Her vital signs revealed a fever of 101.8°F, blood pressure of 140/88 mmHg, heart rate of 95 bpm, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination was notable for left costovertebral angle tenderness. No abdominal guarding or rebound tenderness was observed. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory findings revealed a leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16,000/mm³, as well as elevated inflammatory markers (CRP 45 mg/L). Urinalysis showed pyuria and bacteriuria, with the presence of white blood cell casts suggesting upper urinary tract involvement. Blood cultures were taken before the initiation of antibiotics.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics, specifically ceftriaxone, given her allergy to penicillin reported in the past. She was hydrated aggressively with IV fluids. The patient's fever resolved by the third hospital day, and flank pain significantly improved. Blood and urine cultures eventually grew E. coli, sensitive to the administered antibiotic. Endocrinology was consulted to assist with diabetic management given the infection. She was transitioned to oral antibiotics and educated on the importance of complete adherence to the antibiotic regimen. With stable vital signs and improvement in her clinical condition, she was discharged home on day five with a seven-day course of oral ciprofloxacin. Follow-up was arranged with her primary care physician to monitor her recovery and diabetic control.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Newly diagnosed Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus with poor glycemic control 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 46-year-old female, working as a high school teacher, who presented to the hospital with complaints of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds over the past three months, and excessive thirst and urination. The symptoms had been progressively worsening, prompting her visit to her primary care physician. Initial laboratory tests revealed a significantly elevated blood glucose level of 320 mg/dL, leading to her referral to the hospital for further management and education on diabetes.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, diagnosed five years ago, currently managed with lisinopril. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia, for which she takes atorvastatin. There is a family history of diabetes; her father was diagnosed at age 55. She has no known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption, typically enjoying a glass of wine with dinner several times a week. She leads a sedentary lifestyle, attributing it to her busy work schedule and family responsibilities, which include caring for her two teenage children. Her diet consists of high carbohydrate meals, with a particular fondness for pasta dishes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient is alert and oriented, with vital signs showing blood pressure 138/86 mmHg, heart rate 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. She is overweight, with a BMI of 30. Skin examination reveals mild acanthosis nigricans on the neck. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory results on admission confirmed elevated fasting glucose levels of 290 mg/dL and an HbA1c of 9.2%, indicating poor long-term glycemic control. Serum electrolytes were within normal limits, and renal function was adequate. Lipid profile demonstrated elevated LDL cholesterol at 160 mg/dL, further necessitating management adjustments.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was started on metformin and advised on insulin therapy to gain immediate glycemic control, along with a tailored diabetic diet. A consultation with a diabetes educator was conducted to provide the patient with comprehensive lifestyle modifications, emphasizing the importance of diet and regular exercise. She was educated on monitoring her blood glucose levels and recognizing signs of hypo- and hyperglycemia. During her hospital stay, she attended daily educational sessions that focused on diabetes self-management. The patient expressed a strong willingness to adopt these changes and was enrolled in a follow-up care program. By the end of her hospital stay, her blood glucose levels showed improvement, and she was discharged with a plan for an outpatient follow-up with her endocrinologist in two weeks to further assess her treatment regimen.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 67-year-old retired high school teacher who presented to the emergency department with a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis, confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
She started experiencing persistent right upper quadrant abdominal pain three days prior to admission, worsened by fatty foods, with associated nausea and vomiting. She initially treated her symptoms with anti-emetics and antacids but decided to seek medicalattention when the pain became severe and was accompanied by a fever.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has a notable medical history, but she does not suffer from anemia, and her most recent blood count was normal. However, due to complications from a previous knee replacement, her doctor prescribed her a course of tranexamic acid and ibuprofen. A detailed review of her records shows that one of her relatives was diagnosed with a blood disorder and received plasma as part of her treatment.

SOCIAL HISTORY
She lives alone in a one-bedroom house, and her daughter who lives a few blocks away checks in on her twice a day. The patient smoked cigarettes until she was in her late 50s and has reduced her intake of high-fat foods after being informed of the link between those foods and an increased heart disease risk.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Her abdomen appeared tender throughout, with a positive Murphy sign. The vital signs on admission included blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg and temperature 101.2 F.

LABORATORY DATA
Lab results indicated elevated liver enzymes, amylase 135 units/L and lipase of 250 units/L were essentially normal while WBC was elevated to 14,900 cells/L. An attempt to correct metabolic disturbances using crystalloids helped manage her symptoms until surgical evaluation for probable gallbladder disease could take place. Upon evaluation prior to surgery it appears she required close observation to correct potential electrolyte imbalances.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 67-year-old retired librarian with hypertension presenting with dyspnea and chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNSS
Patient reports having difficulty breathing over the past two days with worsening chest discomfort radiating to her left lateral chest and arm, prompting her to visit the emergency department.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
She has type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and sitagliptin and has been on lisinopril for her hypertension. The patient also has a previous history of gastric ulcers, and has been found to have atrial fibrillation in the past, which is currently controlled with a beta-blocker.

SOCIAL HISTORY
Patient is a lifelong nonsmoker and consumes alcohol very infrequently, typically limiting herself to one glass of wine monthly. Physical activity is restricted due to mobility and back issues but reports a good adherence to her medication regiment.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Vital signs on admission reveal tachycardia at 110 beats per minute along with a low peripheral capillary oxygen saturation of 85% without the supplemental oxygen that had been given upon arrival. Her neurological check reveals slight dizziness but no clear focal neurological deficits upon initial clinical assessment.

LABORATORY DATA
Corticosteroids had not recently been used, her platelet level was within acceptable parameters but marginally low, suggesting mild thrombocytopenia. The troponin T level, was however found to be slightly elevated indicating possible myocardial tissue stress or mild injury, a chest X-ray had not suggested the occurrence of hemoptysis which was within the realm of diagnostic differentials given the history and symptoms.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Admission involved oxygenation as initial care step alongside titration to pain management as needed. An anticoagulant reversal agent became necessary, following a brief but necessary intravenous administration of heparin required during a vascular procedural management attempt prior to deciding on further invasive diagnostics being deemed potentially risky due a bleeding complication concern. After thorough analysis by cardiologists and the multidisciplinary teams a final decision of non-invasive approach was taken instead resulting in patient management consisting of optimized pharmacologic support which showed significant symptom remission leading up to discharge home on maximized medical management therapies adjusted from original regimen to include additional agents.

The furosemide dosage was adjusted downward slightly with monitoring of peripheral edema by her primary care physician after a nephrology consult in collaboration on her treatment to manage chronic peripheral and possibly diuretic exacerbated renal symptoms. ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The patient is a sixty-year-old retired mechanic who presented to the emergency department with symptoms of acute kidney impairment secondary to obstructive nephropathy due to kidney stones. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient reported experiencing severe abdominal pain radiating to his back accompanied by nausea and vomiting for approximately two days. He admitted to taking over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications, including acetaminophen to help manage symptoms but with little relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
He has hypertension for which he is treated with losartan and atorvastatin for elevated cholesterol. His history of recurrent kidney stones necessitates periodic follow-up and monitoring.

SOCIAL HISTORY
As an avid smoker for nearly four decades and an active coffee drinker, there was concern about potential effects of caffeine and nicotine. The patient lives alone in his house but relies heavily on his family for support. Following discussions about his condition and treatment plan, modifications to his lifestyle were agreed upon to prevent future episodes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Clinical findings revealed left costovertebral angle tenderness, indicative of the obstructive process, and significant weight loss was noticed in recent times due to the poor oral intake in response to discomfort. Examination otherwise did not detect abnormal physical findings aside from those that pointed towards severe dehydration status on clinical exam.

LABORATORY DATA 
Blood samples at hospitalization demonstrated elevations of creatinine at 2.5 mg/dl, a reflection of renal function impairment. Urinalysis showed the findings of significant bacteriuria. Serum calcium and phosphorus levels fell within normal limits with an unRemarkable liver panel.

HOSPITAL COURSE
The clinical approach entailed aggressive fluid management including normal saline solution alongside analgesic support as acetaminophen to mitigate discomfort from ureteral colic pain episodes until stone fragments had passed through and pain dissipated with successful treatment of acute condition during his hospital stay. Intravenous antibiotic to cover gram-negative bacilli infections causing pyelonephritis were administered after identifying and interpreting lab tests from urinalysis indicating a urinary-tract-infection requiring hospital care. Monitoring showed recovery towards the normal limits of kidney function parameters as hydration replenished volume status over several hospital days resulting in discharge with oral medications that manage his symptoms posthospital care.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Uncontrolled hypertension and chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 62-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of intermittent chest discomfort, worsening exertional dyspnea, and a severe headache. He described the chest pain as a pressure-like sensation, not associated with nausea or diaphoresis, but noted transient relief with rest. The headache began simultaneously with the chest pain and has been persistent, dull, and located predominantly in the frontal region. He denies any visual aura or photophobia but does report mild nausea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension, diagnosed 15 years ago, and hyperlipidemia. He was previously non-compliant with antihypertensive therapy due to perceived side effects. A past adverse reaction to lisinopril was noted. No history of diabetes or past strokes. Surgical history includes an appendectomy performed in his 20s. He also experiences seasonal allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a retired postal worker who lives with his spouse. He is a former smoker, having quit approximately ten years ago, but has a 25-pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially, approximately 1-2 glasses of wine per week. His physical activity level has decreased since his retirement, now primarily consisting of walking short distances. There is no history of illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared slightly diaphoretic and in mild distress due to chest pain. His blood pressure was 172/98 mmHg, heart rate was 88 beats per minute, respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute, and he was afebrile. Cardiovascular examination revealed a regular heart rate and rhythm without murmurs. Lung examination was clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdominal examination was unremarkable. Neurological examination was notable for the absence of focal deficits, and pupils were equal and reactive to light.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory tests showed elevated cholesterol levels and a slight increase in creatinine, indicating possible renal compromise due to poorly controlled hypertension. Cardiac enzymes were negative, but an EKG showed nonspecific ST-segment changes. A chest X-ray was normal, and a CT scan of the head ruled out acute intracranial pathology.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the cardiology service for management of hypertensive crisis and possible ischemic heart disease. He was started on intravenous nitroglycerin and oral beta-blockers, which resulted in improved blood pressure control and reduction of chest pain. A stress test was subsequently performed and indicated probable coronary artery disease, leading to a further investigation with coronary angiography, which demonstrated moderate stenosis in two coronary vessels. This condition was managed conservatively with medication adjustments, including the addition of a calcium channel blocker and a statin. For his headaches, an alternative antihypertensive was added. The patient responded well to the changes, with resolution of the severe headache and an improvement in chest pain. He was discharged after four days in stable condition with a follow-up appointment planned with his primary care physician and a referral to a cardiologist for ongoing management of his cardiovascular risk factors. Lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and a walking regimen, were emphasized upon discharge.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute myocardial infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 58-year-old male, Mr. Robert Johnson, who presented to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw, associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The chest pain began approximately two hours prior to his ER visit while he was working at his job as a construction foreman. He took two doses of sublingual nitroglycerin with no relief, prompting his wife to drive him to the hospital for further evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Johnson has a significant medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, all of which have been managed with medication. He is on lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He has no history of previous cardiac events. He is up to date on his age-appropriate cancer screenings and vaccinations.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Johnson lives with his wife in a suburban area and has two adult children. He is a lifelong smoker with a 40 pack-year history but plans to quit after his cardiac event. He drinks alcohol socially, about 2-3 times per week. Physical activity is sporadic, primarily due to his demanding occupation, but he enjoys fishing and walks on weekends.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the emergency department, Mr. Johnson appeared in moderate distress due to chest pain. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg, heart rate of 102 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination showed no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Lung fields were clear to auscultation, and the examination of other systems was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial troponin T was elevated at 0.15 ng/mL, which increased to 1.2 ng/mL on subsequent testing. ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, consistent with an inferior myocardial infarction. Additional laboratory tests revealed elevated fasting glucose and LDL cholesterol levels.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He was promptly taken to the cardiac catheterization lab, where a coronary angiogram exhibited a critical stenosis in the right coronary artery. A drug-eluting stent was successfully placed, restoring adequate blood flow. Post-procedurally, he was monitored in the cardiac care unit, where he remained hemodynamically stable. He was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, alongside appropriate management of his diabetes and hypertension.

In preparation for discharge, Mr. Johnson received comprehensive education on lifestyle modifications, including smoking cessation, dietary changes, and the importance of regular physical activity. Cardiopulmonary rehabilitation was recommended. He was discharged home on hospital day four with a follow-up visit scheduled with his cardiologist in two weeks to assess his recovery and compliance with his medical regimen. Mr. Johnson expressed gratitude for the care provided and a strong commitment to improving his heart health.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
Pneumonia in a twenty-five-year-old graduate student admitted with worsening shortness of breath and cough over two weeks.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
This patient's acute illness began with general fatigue and a sore throat, quickly progressing to include cough and difficulty breathing. Over the two-week period, she experienced night sweats and lost seven pounds despite having an unusually good appetite. Prior to this episode, she felt perfectly healthy and was physically very active with a part-time job as an aerobics instructor. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
Her chronic conditions include mild intermittent asthma controlled using occasional doses of an albuterol inhaler. She reported receiving the flu and Covid vaccines as recommended during her regular physical exams at a college clinic. In childhood, a mild penicillin allergy with rash occurred. All dental issues, she said, were handled in a college oral clinic that managed students on her dental plan, but did not detail the treatment or specific diagnoses other than some minor cavities that were corrected.

SOCIAL HISTORY 
Socially, this individual reported heavy cigarette and periodic hookah usage since age nineteen alongside an increasingly sedentary lifestyle from working extended hours preparing lesson plans as a recent educator.  However, as physical education instructor, her schedule allowed a mix of physical activity during work as instructor with heavy student population of younger children. This lifestyle transition was accompanied by irregular use of alcohol on social engagements over many past social weekends while enjoying nightlife music and events on weekends but has significantly decreased such use following some recent life events in favor other pursuits outside teaching field now more frequently pursued instead in recent personal time outside that job description that now has allowed some return of physical activity outside work schedule as part of leisure or fun again without that past sedentary routine at home previously so predominant.


PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 
Her vitals presented an oral temperature of 101.9 Fahrenheit along with pulse of 106, BP was 128/74 mm/Hg. Pulse-Ox revealed an oxygen saturation of 92% in room air upon intake at ER, later corrected using oxygen at increasing Fi0 percentages until adequate. Rales and other sounds detected at left lung on exam were indicative of left lobe consolidation. 

LABORATORY DATA 
Blood cell differentials did suggest mild elevated WBCs at nearly twice baseline with elevated markers and bands observed upon manual review. Radiology imaging from the portable antero-post views demonstrated increased infiltration at lung fields bilaterally and especially in a lobe, but less in right side, thus, supporting our impression in ER after thorough review of diagnostic data.

HOSPITAL COURSE 
Antibacterial treatment of ampicillin and sulfactant combination given empirically on intake for coverage of likely cause pending additional lab confirmation which later became positive in the following forty-eight hours as blood results came back and confirmed a specific gram stain and final cultures, later fully identifying and isolating Pneumococcus in a respiratory lab.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Pneumonia, secondary to influenza infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mark Henderson, a 47-year-old high school biology teacher, presented to the emergency department with a five-day history of fever, chills, and a persistent, productive cough. He reported increasing shortness of breath over the past two days and noted that his sputum had become progressively darker. Mark initially attributed his symptoms to a seasonal cold but sought medical attention due to the escalation in severity and persistent high fevers.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mark has a history of hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril 10 mg daily. He was diagnosed with asthma in his adolescence but has had minimal exacerbations in recent years. His last asthma-related hospitalization occurred during college. He had surgery for an appendectomy at age 23. He is up-to-date with his vaccinations and had his influenza vaccination last season.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mark lives with his wife and two sons, ages 14 and 17, in a suburban neighborhood. He is a non-smoker and exercises regularly by cycling twice a week. He denies any illicit drug use and drinks alcohol socially, mainly on weekends, estimating approximately four drinks per week. His job as a teacher often exposes him to various infectious agents, given the nature of the school environment.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mark appeared pale and was in mild respiratory distress. His temperature was 102.1°F, with a pulse of 108 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 138/85 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe with coarse crackles. No wheezing was noted. Heart sounds were regular, and no murmurs were detected. Abdominal and neurological examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/µL, predominantly neutrophils. C-reactive protein levels were elevated, confirming significant inflammation. Blood cultures were pending, but an initial rapid influenza test returned positive. A chest X-ray demonstrated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. 

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mark was admitted to the general medical floor for intravenous antibiotics and supportive care. He received IV ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin to cover for atypical bacterial pathogens. Supplemental oxygen was provided via nasal cannula, and his oxygenation levels improved quickly. Respiratory therapy initiated a regimen of incentive spirometry to aid lung expansion. By day three, Mark's fever subsided, and his respiratory symptoms began to improve. His oxygen requirements decreased, allowing for weaning off assistance by day four. Blood cultures eventually showed no bacterial growth. After a five-day hospital stay, Mark was discharged home with a 7-day course of oral antibiotics and instructions to follow up with his primary care physician within one week for a reassessment of his respiratory status. Educational material on preventing future respiratory infections, including hand hygiene and updated vaccination strategies, was provided before discharge.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 42-year-old firefighter with a primary diagnosis of severe pneumonia, likely acquired through inhalation of smoke particles and debris during a recent rescue operation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient was admitted to the hospital after presenting to the emergency department with complaints of high fever, persistent cough, and shortness of breath. The symptoms started about two days before admission, following a particularly grueling fire rescue mission. Over the past year, the patient has experienced similar bouts of respiratory distress, though less severe.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has a long history of chronic bronchitis, asthma, and a previous instance of kidney stones, treated conservatively without needing surgery. Additionally, he suffered from hepatitis B at the age of twenty, which completely resolved following interferon therapy. He has been on inhalation corticosteroids for the asthma.

 SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient is married, a nonsmoker, and only consumes alcohol socially. His work involves intense physical exertion, particularly under conditions exposing him to carcinogenic materials in combustion products and incomplete particles in smoke. When feasible, he exercises regularly to maintain a good fitness level required for his job.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Upon a physical exam, the patient shows signs of respiratory distress with labored breathing, use of accessory muscles to assist breathing, a temperature of 103.2 degrees Fahrenheit, and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Examination also revealed evidence of wheezing over all lung fields. He was tachycardic but did not show clinical evidence of acute cardiac distress.

LABORATORY DATA
Initial lab tests confirmed the presence of leukocytosis with differential counts showing an increase in band forma neutrophils, indicative of severe infection. Arterial blood gas results demonstrated low PaO2 consistent with respiratory compromise, necessitating early intubation in critical care to support respiration until his oxygen saturation level normalized.

HOSPITAL COURSE
His condition has been managed aggressively, including antibiotic therapy, supportive respiratory measures like non-invasive and then invasive mechanical ventilation, careful hydration, and monitoring in the intensive care unit for clinical stability prior to a possible transfer to a step-down or acute care unit. His kidney function also warranted continuous monitoring during therapy, given the potential for antibiotic-induced side effects on these organs, along with his pre-existing vulnerability indicated by historical incidents like kidney stones. After careful consideration and clinical discussion involving patient input, possible underlying causative or risk factors for recurrence were reviewed with the intention of mitigating long-term risks upon discharge. Treatment is aimed at completely clearing his current infection, thereby lessening complications associated with this illness in someone of his unique occupation and background. As his health progresses, the team plans to discuss potential adjustments needed for minimizing disease recurrences and optimizing health status during ongoing employment or alternative roles.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 75-year-old retired school teacher with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient was admitted from her home, where she has been experiencing worsening symptoms of fever, chills, and shortness of breath over the past three days. She denies any recent travel or sick contacts. She had been managed as an outpatient with azithromycin but had not seen any improvement, prompting her to visit the emergency department for further evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient's past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, with a drug-eluting stent placed in 2005, and hypertension. She has been taking atenolol and lisinopril, as directed by her primary care physician, to manage these conditions. Her medical history also includes gastroesophageal reflux disease, controlled by omeprazole.

 SOCIAL HISTORY
She lives alone, but family and neighbors help with household and grocery shopping, and are supportive. A history of occasional moderate alcohol consumption, typically in the form of a nightly glass of sherry with friends.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Upon examination, the patient was found to be febrile at 103F. There were crackles heard at the lung fields, with egophony. The remainder of the physical examination revealed tenderness in the abdomen likely as an area referred pain from chest.

LABORATORY DATA
Blood work on admission showed elevations in the patients white blood cell count to a maximum of eighteen, an indicator of infectious or potentially other cause inflammatory origin processes present. Her kidney and a comprehensive hepatic metabolic panel, indicated liver enzyme activity were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Due to an ineffective use from the azithromycin on outpatient, intravenous penicillin therapy has been administered to help resolve the pneumonia infection more rapidly to a state of manageable health so discharge and a successful recovery is feasible at her earliest time for a good quality living situation resuming in her house. Monitoring has been continuous for her blood pressure and a heart health indicator given her extensive background in heart disease for careful consideration and to prevent future risk of an unexpected patient decline.

A fifty-year-old construction worker named Robert Jenkins presented for evaluation following an accidental overdose of his prescribed fentanyl patches. 

Admission diagnosis for Robert included opioid toxicity and respiratory depression secondary to an overuse of his analgesic regimen for chronic back pain from several on-the-job injuries, with the most significant being a lumbar disc herniation sustained about five years prior.

History of present illness notes began with complaints initiated approximately seven days prior to hospitalization. He was experiencing breakthrough back pain despite using his as-directed fentanyl patches and Percocet pills as had been prescribed for management of such exacerbations by his primary care doctor. On day five, his primary caregiver left town, and his pain levels sharply increased; feeling desperate, Robert made two poor choices. First, in addition to applying an excessive number of fentanyl patches to his lower back simultaneously (a decision aimed at accelerating opioid analgesic delivery), Robert then proceeded with unsupervised, self-administered increments of his Percocet, exceeding a quadrupling of dosage recommendations as advised on each respective bottle labeling from pharmacy dispensing for acute episodes management per prior instruction.

As for his past medical history, Robert had suffered an array of physically demanding, injury-prone years on construction projects which cumulatively contributed significant musculoskeletal problems alongside resultant analgesic requirement elevations, but importantly Robert also suffers a co-occurrent medical burden of diagnosed hypercholesterolemia for which atorvastatin is regularly prescribed. 

Robert's social history was uneventful. Being divorced for over fifteen years, he led a simple, routine-dominated lifestyle. Living with him was an elder mother in seventies under regular review by neurologists following an aneurysmal clipping twenty odd seasons back which left left-sided minimal residual upper limb hemiparesis and also on an array of medications including rivaroxaban.

Physical examination on hospitalization showed somnolence; with notable pinpoint pupils bilaterally; with an unremarkable chest radiograph obtained shortly after hospital intake but did reveal somewhat reduced lung volumes suggestive of depressed respiratory effort consistent with a likely fentanyl and oxycodone induced depression of both drive for respiration centrally as well chemoreceptor function blunting at such supranormal dosing of those medications.

On Laboratory data analysis; significantly low pO2 alongside somewhat compensatorily elevated pCO2 were observed alongside mildly elevated aminotransferases presumably secondary due hypoxia from resultant centrally mediated hypoventilation, but were reassuring as to no further worsening on careful follow-up after first initial hours in monitored conditions within intensive unit for a careful titration process involving careful gradual diminuations then wean ultimately of respiratory and further supportive care as he was found also have been a victim of opioid effect on mental performance over that period too which were thought by treating clinician most likely secondary from drug usage.

Hospital course following initial period comprised an incremental weaning regime. With the application of naloxone on hospital arrival rapidly corrected depressed mental status and also rapidly relieved the patient's hypoventilatory state by antagonizing the opioid induced depression.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute ischemic stroke

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 78-year-old retired schoolteacher who was brought to the emergency room by her daughter after experiencing sudden onset of slurred speech and right-sided weakness. These symptoms began approximately two hours prior to her arrival. Her daughter reported that the patient was well and conversing normally earlier that morning when they had breakfast together. She denied any recent trauma, headaches, or seizures, and there was no history of similar episodes in the past.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, which has been poorly controlled, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. She also has a history of osteoarthritis and mild heart failure for which she has been taking prescribed medications including lisinopril, atorvastatin, and warfarin. The patient had an appendectomy in her 40s but otherwise has no significant surgical history.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a widow who lives independently in a retirement community. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She is physically active, attending a bi-weekly tai chi class at her community center. She has two children who live nearby and are her primary support system.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was found to be alert but had dysarthria. She had right-sided facial droop, and weakness was noted in her right arm and leg, with motor power graded as 2/5 on that side. Sensory examination showed decreased sensation on the right side of the body. The rest of the neurological examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests revealed elevated LDL cholesterol levels and an INR of 1.8, which were subtherapeutic given her atrial fibrillation. A CT scan of the head showed early signs of an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. An ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Following the emergency room visit, the patient was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke attributed to cardioembolism given her known atrial fibrillation. She was administered intravenous thrombolysis therapy promptly within the therapeutic window without any complications. Her INR was optimized, and she was transitioned to a direct oral anticoagulant for better stroke prevention management. The patient's blood pressure and cholesterol were managed with an adjusted medication regimen, improving both control and efficacy.

The patient was admitted to the stroke unit, where she underwent a structured rehabilitation program. This included physical, occupational, and speech therapy tailored to regain her motor skills, speech clarity, and independent functionality. The team planned a comprehensive discharge strategy, including home safety assessments and continued outpatient rehabilitation to further enhance her recovery. The patient made gradual improvements over her hospital stay, regaining some motor function on her right side. She was discharged to her daughter's care with a follow-up appointment scheduled with her primary care provider and a cardiologist to assess ongoing stroke risk management.

Patient Name: Lucas Thompson  
Age: 55 years  
Occupation: Construction Worker  
Admission Date: March 10, 2023  
Discharge Date: March 14, 2023

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Lucas Thompson, a 55-year-old male, presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of worsening cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The symptoms began with mild fatigue and a non-productive cough but progressed to dyspnea and chest pain, particularly on inspiration. He denied any recent travels or sick contacts but mentioned continuing to work outdoors despite inclement weather conditions, which could have contributed to his current state.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson's medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he is on lisinopril 10 mg daily. He also has a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis, managed with over-the-counter antihistamines. There is no history of previous respiratory conditions such as asthma, and he has never required hospitalization for pulmonary issues before.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Lucas is a lifelong resident of the area, living with his spouse and two adult children. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history, having quit approximately five years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally but does not use illicit drugs. His work as a construction worker involves physical labor outdoors, even in adverse weather conditions, which may have exposed him to respiratory irritants.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On admission, Lucas appeared acutely ill and was in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs were as follows: temperature 101.5°F, heart rate 105 beats per minute, respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute, blood pressure 136/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation was 89% on room air. Lung auscultation revealed crackles in the right lower lobe. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory investigations showed a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³ indicating leukocytosis. Chest X-ray demonstrated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Influenza and COVID-19 tests were negative, and blood cultures were pending at the time of admission. 

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Thompson was admitted to the medical ward for intravenous antibiotics and supportive care. He was started on ceftriaxone 1g IV daily and azithromycin 500 mg IV on the first day, followed by 250 mg IV daily. Supplemental oxygen was provided via nasal cannula to maintain adequate oxygenation, and he was assessed by the respiratory therapy team for chest physiotherapy to aid in secretion clearance.

Over the next few days, Lucas showed significant clinical improvement. His fever resolved, and he was able to breathe comfortably on room air. Blood cultures remained negative throughout his hospital stay. By day four, he was transitioned to oral antibiotics and discharged home with a prescription for azithromycin 250 mg daily to complete a total of ten days of antibiotic therapy.

At discharge, Lucas was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his primary care physician in one week and was counseled regarding smoking cessation and vaccinations for pneumococcus and influenza to prevent future occurrences. He was in agreement with the plan and expressed determination to adhere to lifestyle modifications and follow-up care.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. James Oliver, a 64-year-old retired postal worker, presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of fever, productive cough, and increasing shortness of breath. He initially experienced a runny nose and sore throat a week ago, which he attributed to seasonal allergies. However, the onset of fever and worsening cough prompted him to seek medical attention. Upon arrival, he reported fatigue and mild chest pain when coughing. He denied any recent travel or known sick contacts.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Oliver has a history of hypertension, which is well-controlled with lisinopril. He also has hyperlipidemia, managed with atorvastatin. He underwent appendectomy in his 20s but has no other significant surgical history. He is up to date with his vaccinations, including the pneumococcal vaccine he received last year.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Oliver is a lifelong non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, approximately 2-3 drinks per week. He lives with his wife in a suburb and enjoys gardening and fishing in his free time. He has two grown children who live out of state. No illicit drug use is reported. He maintains a diet relatively high in fiber but admits to consuming more processed food recently due to reduced mobility from his flu symptoms.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Oliver appeared ill but was alert and oriented, with a temperature of 38.5°C, blood pressure of 136/82 mmHg, heart rate of 98 bpm, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Lung examination revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles over the right lower lobe. Heart sounds were regular, with no murmurs. Abdomen was soft and non-tender, with normal bowel sounds. Extremities were warm, with no edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory studies revealed a white blood cell count of 13,000/mm^3 with neutrophilic predominance. Basic metabolic panel and liver function tests were within normal limits. Blood cultures are pending. Chest X-ray demonstrated right lower lobe consolidation consistent with pneumonia.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Oliver was admitted to the hospital for management of community-acquired pneumonia. He was started on broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His response to treatment was closely monitored with daily physical examinations and repeat laboratory tests to track inflammatory markers. With the initiation of antibiotics, his fever abated within 48 hours, and he showed significant clinical improvement. His cough became less productive, and his oxygen saturation improved, allowing for titration down from supplemental oxygen. Mr. Oliver was encouraged to engage in respiratory physiotherapy to aid in the clearance of pulmonary secretions. By hospital day four, his condition had markedly improved, and he was transitioned to oral antibiotics. He was subsequently discharged on hospital day five with a follow-up appointment in the pulmonology clinic, instructions for home exercises, and education on pneumonia recovery and prevention strategies.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 58-year-old male who presented to the emergency room with a two-hour history of severe, crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck. He described associated symptoms of shortness of breath, nausea, and diaphoresis. He reported that the pain began suddenly while watching television at home. He initially attempted to alleviate the discomfort with over-the-counter antacids which provided no relief, prompting his visit to the ER.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, managed with lisinopril, and hyperlipidemia, for which he is taking atorvastatin. He has no history of diabetes or previous cardiac events. He quit smoking ten years ago after a pack-a-day habit for 20 years. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father who suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is employed as a high school history teacher. He lives with his wife and two teenage children. He is physically active, walking his dogs daily and occasionally playing tennis on the weekends. He reports moderate alcohol consumption, typically a glass of wine with dinner. He denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appears diaphoretic and anxious. Blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, heart rate is 95 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. He has an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Lungs are clear bilaterally. The abdomen is soft, non-tender, with normal bowel sounds. There are no peripheral edema or jugular venous distention.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial EKG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Cardiac enzymes were significantly elevated, with a troponin I level of >0.4 ng/mL. Additional lab work showed normal renal function, and a lipid panel consistent with known hyperlipidemia.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was immediately diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction and received thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in the emergency department. Following the thrombolytic therapy, he was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit for close monitoring. On arrival, he was started on a standard post-MI regimen, including aspirin, beta-blocker, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. He displayed reperfusion arrhythmia which was transient and resolved without intervention. Two days later, a follow-up visit with cardiology confirmed successful thrombolysis and noted substantial improvement in cardiac enzymes and EKG changes. The patient underwent additional lab monitoring that included serial troponins, complete blood count, and metabolic panel to gauge his response and rule out complications. By hospital day three, his symptoms had fully resolved, and he reported no further episodes of chest pain. He was discharged on day four with recommendations for outpatient cardiac rehabilitation, smoking cessation counseling, and dietary modifications. A follow-up visit with his primary care physician was scheduled for the following week, where he will be assessed for ongoing risk factor modification and further adjustments to his medication regimen.
