ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
This patient is a 58 year old male, a retired auto mechanic, admitted with a primary Diagnosis of acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The severity of his condition prompted emergency services intervention at home.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
His condition started 3 days prior to admission, as he experienced progressive worsening of shortness of breath on exertion without significant change in baseline sputum volume or purulence. Over this time he noticed increasing chest discomfort, described as an aching sensation exacerbated with deeper respiration. The day of admission, symptoms further worsened with notable increased wheezing which led his daughter to seek emergency medical intervention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease diagnosed 10 years ago, treated with medication that includes tiotropium and as needed allotuerol inhalers. Hypertension diagnosis followed 5 years later for which he takes enalapril daily. Notably he has been experiencing non-specific musculoskeletal discomfort intermittently treated with NSAIDs under doctor consultation due to renal concerns with prolonged use. There's also been ongoing management for mild persistent asthma identified a decade ago after recurrent seasonal flare-ups.

SOCIAL HISTORY
Patient was an ardent recreational cyclist with frequent community involvement until mobility issues started 5 years back which saw noticeable reduction. His home environment accommodates mobility limitations well but has no reported second-hand smoke exposure. Although he quit smoking twenty-eight years before the current admission, a past three decadelong history of one pack each day remains an essential risk marker.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Initial vital signs indicated mild tachycardia but were within acceptable range. On respiratory exam, decreased breath sounds and wheezes bilaterally most apparent upon auscultation on the left lower lung fields supported need for oxygen therapy initiated promptly post evaluation.

LABORATORY DATA
Admission tests showed mildly deranged blood gases indicative of hypoventilation along expected increased D-Dimer to just over twice reference, which could suggest an acute pulmonary stress event on the COPD background.

HOSPITAL COURSE
After comprehensive review of patient symptoms, history and current lab values an adjustment of current management protocols including titration downward on NSAIDs given potential contribution to current acute status of decompensated condition, and optimization of his inpatient treatment protocols resulted in gradual and satisfactory recovery allowing discharge to an early follow-on facility after five days total time as inpatients of this unit. Discharge was further contingent to his being free of supplemental medication except inhalers and with arrangements ensured for subsequent follow-up pulmonary function and clinical visits. The treatment plan adjustments will enable better management of potential side effects experienced from other prescribed medication including his hypertension pills to mitigate further kidney strain risk from NSAID discontinuation which would necessitate ongoing surveillance of blood creatinines every trimester as suggested from literature evidence to manage risks effectively for his renal function to be monitored going forward from an informed care provider viewpoint based on past patient interactions and outcomes from clinical decisions previously taken by healthcare practitioners treating the subject patient population.

Patient Name: Samuel Rodriguez  
Age: 46  
Gender: Male  
Occupation: Construction Worker  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Appendicitis.  

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. Rodriguez presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of progressively worsening abdominal pain, primarily localized to the right lower quadrant. The pain was initially diffuse and associated with nausea and a low-grade fever. He reported a decreased appetite and noted that the pain was exacerbated by movement. He denied changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms.  

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, which is well-controlled on lisinopril. He experienced a right ankle fracture five years ago, which fully healed without complications. There is no history of previous abdominal surgeries.  

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Rodriguez lives at home with his wife and two children. He works as a construction worker and is physically active, though he admits to not getting regular exercise outside of work. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history, having quit smoking two years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol on weekends and denies any illicit drug use.  

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Rodriguez was in mild distress due to pain. He was afebrile with stable vital signs, although he had mild tachycardia. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness localized to the right lower quadrant with guarding and rebound tenderness noted. Bowel sounds were present but decreased. Murphy’s sign was negative. Cardiovascular and respiratory exams were unremarkable.  

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count demonstrated leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³ with a left shift. Electrolytes and renal function were within normal limits. An ECG was performed due to the patient’s history of hypertension and showed signs consistent with left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute changes. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed appendicitis with no evidence of rupture.  

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Rodriguez was admitted to the surgical unit and underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy the following morning. The procedure was uncomplicated, and he was started on a course of intravenous antibiotics post-operatively. His pain was managed with NSAIDs, and he was able to tolerate oral intake on the first postoperative day. He demonstrated good recovery and was discharged on postoperative day two with instructions to follow a light diet and avoid heavy lifting for four weeks. He was scheduled for a follow-up visit with his surgeon in two weeks to assess his recovery and ensure appropriate wound healing. Upon discharge, he received lifestyle counseling focusing on smoking cessation and the importance of maintaining a healthy weight and blood pressure.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Jane Thompson, a 29-year-old school teacher, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of worsening abdominal pain. She described a sharp, persistent pain in the right lower quadrant that began diffusely around the umbilicus. Jane also reported experiencing nausea and anorexia, as well as a low-grade fever measured at home. Her last bowel movement was two days prior to admission, and she noted a decrease in appetite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Jane has a medical history significant for mild persistent asthma, for which she uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. She has no history of surgeries and no known drug allergies. She underwent a tonsillectomy at age 12 and has been generally healthy since.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Jane lives with her partner and a 2-year-old son in a suburban neighborhood. She is a non-smoker, occasionally consumes alcohol socially, and reports no illicit drug use. She maintains an active lifestyle, regularly jogging three times a week, and is keen on healthy eating, although recently her routine was disrupted due to a school examination period.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Jane was found to be in moderate distress due to pain. Her temperature was 100°F, heart rate 98 beats per minute, blood pressure 118/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant with rebound tenderness and guarding. Rovsing's sign was positive. Bowel sounds were normoactive.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory studies revealed a white blood cell count of 15,000/mm³, indicating leukocytosis. Hemoglobin and platelet counts were within normal limits. A Comprehensive Metabolic Panel was unremarkable. Urinalysis was negative for infection. An abdominal ultrasound suggested an inflamed appendix, and a subsequent CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, showing a dilated appendix measuring 1.2 cm with surrounding fat stranding.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Jane was diagnosed with acute appendicitis and promptly admitted for surgical evaluation. She underwent a successful laparoscopic appendectomy without complications. Postoperatively, Jane was prescribed a course of intravenous antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and metronidazole, to cover any potential intra-abdominal infections. Pain was managed effectively with acetaminophen and, when necessary, low-dose narcotics.

Jane recovered well, with the surgical team noting no signs of complications such as infection or bowel obstruction. She was ambulated on postoperative day one and progressed to a regular diet without difficulty. By day two, she was passing flatus, and bowel function had returned to normal. Physical therapy was not deemed necessary, and discharge planning was initiated. 

Jane was discharged home on postoperative day three with instructions to rest and limit physical activity for at least two weeks. She was educated on wound care and signs of infection, and a follow-up appointment was scheduled with the surgical team in two weeks to monitor her recovery.

Patient Records of John Ellis

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Ellis, a 62-year-old retired high school teacher, arrived at the emergency department with severe central chest pain that began suddenly while he was gardening. He described the pain as a heavy pressure radiating to his left arm and jaw, accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. The symptoms started about one hour prior to his arrival, prompting his wife to bring him to the hospital quickly.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Ellis has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which are managed with daily lisinopril and atorvastatin, respectively. He underwent an appendectomy at age 15 and has no known allergies. He reports a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes managed with metformin, with generally good glycemic control.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Ellis is a lifelong non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally, with a preference for wine on the weekends. He is physically active, enjoying hiking and gardening several times a week. He lives with his wife and has two adult children who live nearby. He adheres to a moderately healthy diet, skewing towards Mediterranean-style meals.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Ellis appeared acutely distressed by the severe chest pain. Vital signs showed hypertension with an initial blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs were clear to auscultation, and no lower extremity edema was noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Troponin levels were significantly elevated at 5.2 ng/mL. An electrocardiogram demonstrated ST-elevation in the inferior leads, confirming an acute myocardial infarction. A complete blood count and metabolic panel were unremarkable, except for a slightly elevated glucose level, likely stress-induced.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Ellis was quickly stabilized in the emergency room and taken for urgent cardiac catheterization, which revealed a 90% stenosis in the right coronary artery. He underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement. Post-procedure, he was monitored in the coronary care unit for 48 hours and started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, along with an increase in his statin dose. During his stay, he was educated on the significance of lifestyle modifications and medication adherence to prevent further cardiac events. His diabetes management was reviewed, and an endocrinology consult was arranged to optimize his regimen.

FOLLOW-UP VISIT: At Mr. Ellis's follow-up appointment two weeks post-discharge, he reported significant improvement with no recurrence of chest pain or dyspnea. His blood pressure was well controlled, and he was compliant with his medications. Plans were made to follow up with his primary care physician and a cardiac rehabilitation program was recommended to enhance his recovery and promote cardiovascular health.

Admission Diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia

The patient is a sixty-five-year-old retired mathematics teacher who presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of worsening cough, fevers, and shortness of breath. She has a complex past medical history notable for follicular lymphoma, for which she underwent chemotherapy six months ago, resulting in significant neutropenia that was successfully managed with recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. Additionally, she suffers from well-controlled hypertension on lisinopril and long-standing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease that is managed with albuterol and fluticasone inhalers.

The patient's social history is significant for having been born and raised in the rural Midwest, where her lifelong occupational exposures on her family's farm are relevant, including exposure to various animals and farming chemicals. A lifelong nonsmoker, she consumes moderate amounts of alcohol and has never used illicit substances. Her current living situation includes her partner of forty years in a small town with adequate healthcare facilities within walking distance.

Physical examination reveals a cachectic-appearing elderly woman with diminished bilateral lower lobe lung sounds and mild intercostal retractions. Blood oxygen saturation is markedly diminished, requiring immediate oxygen supplementation. Neurologically, the patient exhibits decreased mental status with disorientation and acute changes in affect.

Initial lab work reveals a severe leukopenia with absolute neutrophil counts less than three hundred, an elevated lactic acid, and evidence of significant chronic kidney disease with mildly elevated phosphorous levels and reduced glomerular filtration rate consistent with the effects of chemotherapy. An echocardiogram is pending as a further step of her diagnostic workup to evaluate for signs of pneumonia-related cardiomyopathy and heart complications from long term exposures to anthracycline therapy used during the treatment of lymphoma.

During the course of her stay, despite her critical state on admission and preexisting risk factors exacerbating complications from the current medical illness and therapy including profound periods of persistent neutropenia post chemotherapy she steadily improves following aggressive antibiotics therapy and recombinant growth factor supplement as part of her plan for managing risks associated neutropenia while an extensive and prolonged regimen targeting pneumonia remains part therapy under continued watch at hospital intensive care unit. The patient's treatment is being redefined every step of the healing progress considering every medication given with the utmost vigilance with regards potential toxic drug reactions due previous history anthracyclines in her chemotherapy and its adverse reactions on cardiac functions monitored on real-time throughout.

Admission diagnosis: the 57-year-old female accountant is being treated for cardiac tamponade, suspected pacemaker lead malfunction, and methicotine valve endocarditis on the mitral-positioned biological St Jude epic valve implant. 

History of present illness: The patient presented at the cardiology department emergency triage two days ago, after noticing decreased exercise tolerance and episodes of syncope. Following an acute coronary intervention the prior year for inferior wall myocardial infarction, she had uneventfully undergone surgical implantation of a pacemaker five-months prior for symptomatic second-degree A-V block Mobitz II type.

Past medical history: aside from hypertension treated for twenty two years, diabetes since the last eleven years managed on insulin and oral medications, and the aforementioned cardiovascular issues necessitating surgical interventions, hyperlipidemia is also noted, albeit on a high-intensity rosuvastatin maintenance regimen that has shown optimal lipid profiling control.

Social history: an unemployed husband supports the patient with two working adolescent children at home. Her mother suffered chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in her terminal months though otherwise no known strong inherited disease markers besides paternal first-degree history of myocardial pathology exist.

Physical examination at intake reveals decreased oxygenation in room airflow without supplemental aid and bilateral pretibial edema of the extremities without radiated pain, consistent with congestive heart signs seen during bedside echocardiographic assessments showing significant elevated right-ventriclar pressures in line with suspected tampon physiology. 

Laboratory data is indicative of slightly compromised global function based upon serum analysis but otherwise unaltered liver, coag, cbc panels outside slight elevations on the liver function enzymes, likely due in a significant portion to current heart pump dysfunction leading to possible acute peri hepatic congestion.

Hospital course reveals patient rejection of pacemaker reposition due initially to patient preference despite explained risks on life and function maintenance which was reconsidered on multidisciplinary discussions including cardiology team input following observed fluctuating pacemaker malfunction parameters over her second monitored full 24-hour period post event which prompted an emergency cardio-thoracic discussion around St Jude implantable bio valve replacement with cardioverter-defribillator/pacemaker integration for definitive medical care solution in patient who had previously undergone valve implant on the mitral-position and pacemaker device implant within 8 months for endstage ischemic combined symptomatic bradi-tachy arrhythmia disorders with associated ischemic and non ischemic related advanced heart failure in its functional capacity class II stage.

Patient Name: Jennifer L., a 48-year-old librarian

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute cholecystitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Jennifer L., a 48-year-old Caucasian female with a sudden onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, presented to the emergency department. The pain started two days prior to admission, described as sharp and constant, radiating to her back. She reported associated nausea and a few episodes of vomiting. She denied fever and jaundice. The symptoms exacerbated after meals, particularly fatty ones, prompting her visit to the emergency department.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Jennifer has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. She also has hypertension managed with lisinopril. She has no history of prior abdominal surgeries or significant illnesses. Her family history is significant for gallstones in her mother.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Jennifer is a librarian who enjoys reading and spends much of her time sitting. She does not smoke or use recreational drugs. She consumes alcohol socially, approximately one to two glasses of wine per week. Her diet includes high fiber but occasional indulgences in rich fatty foods. She lives with her husband and has two adult children in college. She exercises minimally due to her sedentary job.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Jennifer was afebrile with stable vital signs. Her abdominal exam revealed tenderness in the right upper quadrant with a positive Murphy's sign. No rebound tenderness or guarding was observed. Her lungs were clear to auscultation, and heart sounds were normal.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory work showed mild leukocytosis of 11,500/mm³. Liver function tests revealed mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase but normal bilirubin levels. An abdominal ultrasound suggested the presence of gallstones and a thickened gallbladder wall, consistent with acute cholecystitis.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Jennifer was admitted to the surgical service for management of acute cholecystitis. She was started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics for prophylaxis. Pain management was achieved with intravenous acetaminophen and limited opiates. After comprehensive discussions, Jennifer consented to a laparoscopic cholecystectomy which was performed on the second hospital day. The surgery was uneventful, and she tolerated the procedure well with minimal postoperative pain.

Postoperatively, Jennifer was advanced to a clear liquid diet, then a low-fat diet as tolerated. She ambulated early to prevent atelectasis and thrombosis. Her recovery was straightforward, and she was discharged home on the fourth day of admission with instructions to avoid fatty foods and a follow-up appointment in the surgery clinic in one week for suture removal and progress evaluation. During her hospitalization, Jennifer received counseling on the benefits of moderate exercise to enhance recovery and overall health. She expressed motivation to adopt regular walking as part of her daily routine after experiencing the impact of her condition.

A 72-year-old retired librarian was admitted to the medical unit with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath and bilateral leg swelling over the past week. The admission diagnosis was congestive heart failure precipitated by dietary noncompliance and inadequate fluid management.

The patient had a history ofpresent illness marked by gradual onset of fatigue, with episodes of orthopnea necessitating multiple pillows for sleeping. She denied chest discomfort but reported a significant increase in her belt size requiring a new wardrobe. In the two days prior to admission, she suffered mild urinary incontinence episodes prompting her to restrict oral fluid intake despite a previous provider counseling her that doing this might precipitate more severe symptoms.

The patient has a complex medical history notable for atrial fibrillation on Warfarin, hypertension on an Ace inhibitor and beta blocker, well-controlled diabetes type 2 using insulin Aspart, and stable severe chronic obstruction sleep apnea utilizing an oral appliance and continuous oxygen. Her last eye examination for diabetes-related retinopathy found some evidence of diabetic maculopathy requiring an upcoming retina specialist appointment. 

She is married for almost forty-nine years, with adult aged kids that reside close to her house and help in caring responsibilities when health status changes necessitate. The patient's only recreational activity is playing piano due its low- physical impact nature that align perfectly in a gentle rehabilitative program aimed for chronic condition self-managements; she never smokes nor does she consume an excessive alcohol quantities though admits enjoying several small servings of scotch on very rare social meetings with family friends and members.

Upon hospitalization a comprehensive full-body examination demonstrated elevated body temperature at 99F along decreased breath and heart sound regular rhythm. An abdomen fullness noted during bedside inspection was associated and later proved on imaging tests due to ascites secondary from worsening her pre-existed conditions of heart failure state, while an oxygen supplement requirement via 2 liters mask was adjusted several hours during day. Lab results obtained in-house displayed decreased potassium and slight elevation in liver enzymes which were all addressed according management team guidelines with resultant patient's gradual improving.

Laboratory findings, particularly brain natriuretic peptide elevations were concerning and prompted more urgent intervention to manage cardiac function optimization as guided. She improved throughout five total hospital stay days and eventually was stepped down with significant resolution in edema of lower limbs; this was made possibly due adherence of fluid restrictions coupled aggressive medication adjustments that included adding Spironolactone which provided synergistic relief on multiple aspects.

ADMISSON DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a forty-two year old accountant who was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of severe asthma exacerbation, requiring urgent medical attention. Upon admission, it was clear that his condition had deteriorated, necessitating close monitoring and aggressive treatment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Two days prior to admission, the patient developed symptoms of shortness of breath and wheezing which rapidly worsened, despite using his prescribed inhalers. He also experienced a non-productive cough, prompting a visit to the emergency room. The patient recalled an upper respiratory tract infection several weeks prior, but reported that his symptoms had seemed to subside before returning more severely. He denied recent travel but noted an increase in environmental allergens in his area due to pollen season.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has a history of asthma for over two decades, complicated by allergic rhinitis and an atopic nature, leading to frequent allergies to various substances such as dust mites, pet dander, and specific trees and grasses. He has been on a regimen of a combination inhaler for years, adjusted based on the severity of his symptoms and pulmonary function tests. Additionally, he is known to have hypertension managed with a once-daily dosing of medication that he has been adherent with. There is a family history of auto-immune disorders on his mother's side.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient lives a healthy lifestyle overall but admits to not regularly adhering to prescribed exercise schedules due to time constraints. His diet is balanced and he does not have a known drug dependence history. His work environment has been under renovation for several weeks, and colleagues are currently under a stress related to impending lay-offs and restructuring plans, possibly causing him stress.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Upon physical examination, the patient exhibited evidence of moderate respiratory distress, with tachypnea, wheezes bilaterally in the chest and accessory muscle use to supplement breathing, with decreased breath sounds noted. The rest of the examination findings were unremarkable without indication of an acute abdominal or cardiac condition to explain his current complaints. Examination was otherwise normal with normal mental state for orientation.

LABORATORY DATA
An initial metabolic panel indicated slightly elevated glucose levels likely due to acute medication effects, as well all other results within reference limits. Chest X Raymond at time revealed marked diffuse air trapped without signifying consolidation areas.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Over the course of his hospitalization, aggressive measures included intravenous medications to address and manage an airway to open air through passages, alongside oxygen therapy. Close observation of vitals were noted every four hrs alongside lab re-check on third hospital day. Patient education emphasized importance of maintaining strict inhaler and prescribed routine post discharge, including a detailed allergy avoidance guide specifically focused on reducing exposure to pollen during seasons where symptoms tend to increase, to mitigate the occurrence of an acute exacerbation, ensuring the best opportunity possible towards optimal quality patient life at his current and potentially chronic long-standing situation post.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Pneumonia with concurrent acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 72-year-old retired construction worker who presented to the emergency department with increasing shortness of breath, a productive cough with greenish sputum, and low-grade fever for the past three days. He reported worsening dyspnea on exertion and noted that his usual activities within the home had become significantly restricted. The patient mentioned the onset of respiratory symptoms following a recent upper respiratory tract infection, which he attempted to manage at home with over-the-counter medications and his usual COPD inhalers but found no relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a significant history of COPD with frequent exacerbations, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but ceased smoking 10 years ago. His medication regimen includes tiotropium bromide, albuterol inhaler as needed, lisinopril, and atorvastatin.

SOCIAL HISTORY: He lives alone following the passing of his wife six years ago, has two grown children who live out of state, and occasionally receives assistance from a visiting health aide. Despite giving up smoking, he enjoys occasional woodworking in his home workshop. He drinks alcohol socially on weekends and denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon admission, the patient appeared in moderate respiratory distress, with accessory muscle use noted. Blood pressure was 148/88 mmHg, heart rate 96 beats per minute, respiratory rate 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. Upon auscultation, diminished breath sounds with bilateral wheezes and crackles, particularly in the right lower lobe, were evident. The cardiovascular exam was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a left shift. C-reactive protein was elevated, indicating inflammation. An arterial blood gas demonstrated respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation. A chest X-ray revealed right lower lobe consolidation consistent with pneumonia. A sputum culture was obtained for microbiological identification.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward with a diagnosis of pneumonia superimposed on COPD and was started on intravenous antibiotics, respiratory bronchodilators, and corticosteroids. Supplemental oxygen therapy was initiated to maintain adequate oxygen saturation. Pulmonary rehabilitation was consulted to assist with breathing exercises and mobility, and the patient was regularly monitored for any signs of clinical deterioration or improvement. Over the course of his four-day admission, he showed gradual clinical improvement, with resolution of fever and normalizing of respiratory function. Physical therapy recommendations for home respiratory exercises were provided. The patient was counseled on pneumonia prevention, including appropriate periodical vaccinations, and educated on recognizing early symptoms of respiratory infections to seek timely medical attention. He was discharged home on oral antibiotics and instructed to follow up with his primary care physician in one week for re-evaluation and adjustment of his COPD management plan.

Patient Record

Patient Name: Emily Rodriguez  
Age: 26  
Occupation: Graphic Designer

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of asthma.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Emily Rodriguez is a 26-year-old graphic designer who presented to the emergency room with shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness that began suddenly while she was at work. She reported forgetting to carry her inhaler that day. The symptoms started with mild shortness of breath but rapidly progressed over the span of an hour, despite trying to calm herself with breathing exercises, prompting her to come in for an evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Emily was diagnosed with asthma at age 12. Her asthma is generally well-controlled with the use of a daily inhaled corticosteroid (budesonide) and as-needed use of albuterol. Besides asthma, she has a history of seasonal allergies, which have been manageable without prescription medication.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Emily lives in an apartment with her roommate in an urban area. She does not smoke and occasionally drinks alcohol socially. She is physically active and enjoys cycling. There is no significant family history of respiratory illnesses, except for her father, who has hay fever.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, Emily appeared in moderate respiratory distress. Her respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute with accessory muscle use. Auscultation of her lungs revealed bilateral wheezing, more pronounced on expiration. Heart rate was 100 beats per minute, and blood pressure was 122/78 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation on room air was 92%.

LABORATORY DATA: A chest X-ray was performed, which did not show any focal lung consolidation. Arterial blood gas on room air revealed mild respiratory alkalosis (pH 7.46, PaCO2 33 mmHg, PaO2 69 mmHg). Her complete blood count was normal, with no signs of infection.

HOSPITAL COURSE: In the emergency department, Emily received immediate treatment with a nebulized bronchodilator, specifically albuterol, which led to marked improvement in her symptoms. After about an hour, her wheezing had diminished significantly, and her oxygen saturation increased to 97% on room air. She was observed for an additional two hours without recurrence of symptoms and was then discharged home with instructions to start a course of oral prednisone for the next five days to decrease airway inflammation. She was advised to follow up with her primary care physician within the week to review her asthma management plan and ensure proper technique with her inhalers. It was also recommended that she enroll in an asthma education program to reinforce management strategies.

Emily had a follow-up visit six days post-discharge with her primary care physician. During this visit, she showed good compliance with her medication regimen, reported no further episodes, and was educated on identifying triggers and the importance of never leaving home without her inhaler. Adjustments were made to her action plan to prevent future exacerbations.

The clinical patient record for this 75-year-old retired steelworker presents a fascinating case of management challenges. Upon admission, the diagnosis was primarily focused on an acute cerebral vascular accident, which presented as a significant change in the patient's ability to communicate, coupled with sudden-onset weakness on the left side of his body.

During the history of present illness, it was noted that the patient had been experiencing some episodes of confusion and unsteady gait for the past 48 hours, but these became significantly worse approximately 12 hours prior to presentation, leading to a family member recognizing the severe decline and rushing him to the hospital. Notably, the patient is on warfarin for long-term anticoagulation due to his past medical history of atrial fibrillation with an estimated risk score for stroke high enough to warrant such therapy. The social history revealed a nonsmoker, but the patient had been exposed to significant amounts of asbestos during his career, has occasional alcohol intake limited to a few beers during holiday gatherings, and is a widower who lives with one of his daughters who looks after his basic needs but allows him independence.

Physical examination found him oriented in all three spheres but exhibited clear dysarthric speech and profound weakness (graded at about 2 out of 5 on the left upper and lower limbs), suggesting an area on the right side of his brain as the possible origin of this stroke event. A head CT was performed immediately given the patient's anticoagulation status for possible hemorrhage, and laboratory data showed the elevated international normalized ratio consistent with effective warfarin anticoagulation as evidenced also by PT values at over double expected, indicating that an intracranial hemorrhage rather than ischemia had caused his deficits as suspected given warfarin therapy's potential to contribute significantly to the risk and size if an intra-cerberal bleed was to develop.


The CT result confirming a sizable right sided cerebral bleeds' intravenous anticonvulsant therapy given for potential risk of induced clinical seizure, along neuro-intersivenist, input given, management also includes stat dose vitamin k administered alongside activated charcoal per stomach empty given need reverse, anticoag status emergeny situation.


A complex interplay of management options including potential surgery to decompress the intracranial pressures that may threaten life or long-term brain recovery given the severity. His overall prognosis is guarded and is likely be left in moderate to severe deficit status despite optimal treatment given early onset age for significant hemorrhages leading potentially to less recovery than would an ischemic based injury at comparable severity grade for a given cerebral territory. Further close watch under intensive care for the next days monitoring neurological status any sign potential expansion would likely involve a change towards immediate operative intervention for lifesaving efforts despite known inherent high periop risk given the high stakes for patient outcome at the present moment and likely moving forward over next days as case unfolds in dynamic response as indicated in management for intraparanchemal bleeds on coumin treatment as in this case with significant clinical concern.

An elderly retired teacher, aged 72, was admitted to the hospital with severe respiratory distress that had gradually worsened over several days. The patient's admission diagnosis was influenza pneumonia, despite having received the influenza vaccination just a few weeks prior, which appeared to have been ineffective in this case due to the patient's advanced age and underlying chronic medical conditions.

The history of present illness began with complaints of flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, and muscle pains. Initially, the symptoms were mild, but they deteriorated over time. The patient tried to manage the symptoms at home with over-the-counter medications until the onset of severe shortness of breath, at which point she sought emergency medical attention.

The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes type 2, and a past myocardial infarction two years prior. She has been managed on a combination of metformin, atenolol, aspirin, and enalapril for these conditions by her primary care doctor. She has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit ten years ago. Her family history is relevant for coronary artery disease.

Regarding her social history, except for quitting smoking a decade ago, the patient's lifestyle habits haven't significantly changed. She resides with her husband, is generally independent in daily activities, but due to decreased mobility, her outdoor and exercise activities have been limited in recent years.

On physical examination, the patient was feverish, with a temperature of 38.9 degrees Celsius, displayed tachypnea, and had evidence of dehydration. Chest exam findings indicated coarse breath sounds bilaterally, more so in the lower lobes, suggesting consolidation compatible with multifocal pneumonia. Examination of the cardiovascular system showed mild congestive heart failure signs.

Laboratory data upon admission showed leukocytosis with left shift, a significant reduction in PaO2 on arterial blood gas, hyperglycemia at 190 mg/dl, and mildly elevated serum creatinine. Chest X-ray findings confirmed extensive infiltrates in both lungs consistent with multifocal pneumonia.

The hospital course was marked by initial support with noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, aggressive IV hydration, empirical antibiotics for treatment of suspected secondary bacterial infection, and closer monitoring on the step-down unit due to underlying cardiac history and potential risks of rapid fluid overload exacerbating congestive heart failure. Despite showing signs of slight clinical improvement with this treatment regimen, it remains essential to monitor her disease progression closely and tailor the medical intervention correspondingly to maximize recovery chances, highlighting once more the influenza vaccination's ineffectiveness in the context of this case due to age-related immunosenescence.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute back pain due to sciatica.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ms. Lisa Rodriguez, a 44-year-old high school teacher, presented to the emergency room with complaints of severe back pain that began suddenly three days ago. The pain radiated down her left leg and was associated with numbness in the foot. She reported that the onset of the back pain occurred after she helped her friend move some heavy furniture over the weekend, which she attributes as the potential triggering event. The pain was described as sharp and made it difficult for her to stand for extended periods during her classes.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. Rodriguez has a history of hypertension, controlled with lisinopril, and hyperlipidemia, managed with atorvastatin. She has no known drug allergies. She had an appendectomy at age 28, otherwise her surgical history is unremarkable. She has never been hospitalized for any other medical conditions prior to this encounter.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Ms. Rodriguez lives in a suburban area with her husband and two teenage children. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially, approximately one to two glasses of wine per week. She is physically active, usually going for a jog in the local park three to four times a week, though she has been less active lately due to her recent pain. She reports no recreational drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the emergency room, Ms. Rodriguez was in moderate distress due to pain. Vital signs were stable. Examination of the lumbar spine revealed tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles. Positive straight leg raise test on the left side was noted, consistent with sciatic nerve involvement. Neurological examination showed decreased sensation to light touch on the left foot and reduced strength in the left ankle dorsiflexors. Reflexes were symmetric with no upper motor neuron signs.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and inflammatory markers were performed and found to be within normal limits. An x-ray of the lumbar spine showed mild degenerative changes with no acute fractures or subluxations noted. An MRI was scheduled to further evaluate the soft tissue structures and potential nerve compression.

HOSPITAL COURSE: During her hospital stay, the patient was managed with oral analgesics and was educated on sciatica and its usual course. The treating physician initiated a regimen of physiotherapy, focusing on stretching and strengthening exercises for her lumbar spine and lower extremities. The physiotherapy aimed to alleviate nerve compression and reduce inflammation. Ms. Rodriguez responded well to the treatment and was discharged with instructions to continue outpatient physiotherapy. She was also advised on ergonomic adjustments at work to prevent future exacerbations. Follow-up with her primary care provider was arranged to reassess her symptoms and the planned MRI. By discharge, she reported a moderate reduction in pain intensity and improvement in mobility, feeling optimistic about returning to her regular activities.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: James Thompson, a 57-year-old software engineer, presented to the emergency room with acute onset chest pain, described as a crushing sensation radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain began abruptly while he was attending a work meeting and was accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He initially attempted to dismiss the symptoms as indigestion but sought urgent care when the intensity of the pain increased. On arrival at the ER, his electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation, consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: James has a history of hypertension, for which he is on lisinopril. He also has hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin and is a former smoker, having quit five years ago. There is no history of diabetes or previous cardiac events.

SOCIAL HISTORY: James lives with his wife and two teenage children in a suburban neighborhood. He leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle due to his desk job and commutes long distances daily. He enjoys occasional social drinking and denies illicit drug use. Family history is significant for heart disease, with his father having suffered a heart attack at age 60.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, James appeared diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure was 148/92 mmHg, pulse was 104 beats per minute, and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed regular rhythm without murmurs, and lung fields were clear on auscultation.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory tests showed elevated cardiac biomarkers with troponin I levels markedly increased at 3.2 ng/mL. Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits except for slightly elevated cholesterol levels. A chest X-ray showed no acute lung pathology.

HOSPITAL COURSE: James was treated promptly in the emergency room with aspirin, morphine, nitroglycerin, and supplemental oxygen. He was taken urgently for a coronary angiography, which identified a significant occlusion in the left anterior descending artery. He underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement. During his hospital stay, his chest pain resolved, and he was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel in addition to his existing aspirin regimen. His blood pressure medications were optimized, and dietary consultation was provided to address his hyperlipidemia and lifestyle modifications.

James was discharged home in stable condition on the fourth day of hospitalization with instructions for cardiac rehabilitation. During his follow-up visit two weeks post-discharge, he reported feeling well and had adhered to lifestyle changes with increased physical activity and dietary adjustments. His medication adherence was confirmed, and plans were made for continued close monitoring of his cardiac health with routine follow-ups.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: The patient, a 72-year-old retired high school teacher, was admitted with an acute ischemic stroke.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient was brought to the emergency room by her daughter after experiencing sudden weakness on the right side of her body and slurred speech. These events began abruptly at 3 PM, approximately two hours before arriving at the hospital. There was no loss of consciousness or seizure activity noted. Upon arrival at the ER, neurological examinations and imaging confirmed the diagnosis of a left middle cerebral artery stroke.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 20 years, managed with lisinopril. She also has atrial fibrillation for which she has been on warfarin. Notably, her INR levels have been difficult to maintain within the therapeutic range. She has a past history of transient ischemic attack five years ago, with no residual deficits following that event. She also has hyperlipidemia, for which she takes atorvastatin.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives with her husband and remains highly active in her community, volunteering at a local library. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally, primarily when dining out. She has two grown children and frequently enjoys gardening in her spare time.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was alert but had noticeable expressive aphasia. Right-sided hemiparesis was present, with decreased strength graded at 2/5 in the right upper and lower limbs. Her blood pressure was elevated at 180/100 mmHg. Heart auscultation revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm, consistent with atrial fibrillation. Lungs were clear, and no carotid bruits were detected.

LABORATORY DATA: Key laboratory findings included hemoglobin of 13.5 g/dL, INR of 1.5, creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, and total cholesterol of 210 mg/dL. A CT scan of the head showed early signs of ischemia in the left hemisphere, consistent with an acute ischemic stroke.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Upon confirmation of an acute ischemic stroke, the patient was promptly treated with intravenous thrombolysis, as she presented within the therapeutic window. Her symptoms showed partial improvement, particularly in speech, with reduction in aphasia. She was monitored in the ICU for 24 hours following thrombolysis for any conversion to hemorrhagic stroke, during which time she remained stable.

Post-ICU care included the adjustment of her warfarin dosage to achieve a therapeutic INR. A cardiology consult was obtained for optimization of her atrial fibrillation management. The patient was later transferred to a stroke rehabilitation unit where she actively participated in daily physical therapy sessions. The rehabilitation focus included improving mobility, speech therapy for language deficits, and occupational therapy for functional tasks.

By discharge, the patient demonstrated significant gains in her physical abilities, moving independently with a walker, and had substantial improvement in her speech. A comprehensive discharge plan was established, including outpatient follow-up with neurology and cardiology, and continued rehabilitation sessions. The patient's family members were educated about stroke recognition and prevention to prevent future episodes.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient is a 42-year-old female, a professional jazz singer, admitted with a working diagnosis of severe epiglottitis, necessitating urgent evaluation and management.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
She presented to the emergency department with acute-onset progressive dysphagia and odynophagia, along with a fever, which commenced three days prior to admission. Initially, her symptoms were mistaken for a sore throat due to a recent music concert. However, over the succeeding two days, she experienced worsening swallowing difficulties and voice changes. Prior to this illness, she enjoyed good health but mentioned several high-profile performances in dusty environments in the past few weeks.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has a remarkable past medical history significant for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia several years ago, which was followed by a somewhat prolonged recovery characterized by fatigue and mild respiratory issues. She has also had multiple vocal cord surgeries due to recurrent polypoiditis. Her allergy history notable mentions sulfa drugs, causing a skin rash, and a severe allergy to penicillin. The patient is not a smoker but occasionally consumes alcoholic beverages during special events.

SOCIAL HISTORY
This individual resides alone and has a network of colleagues in various artistic disciplines. Despite her demanding career requiring frequent air travel and irregular schedules, she follows a fairly rigorous health regimen which includes yoga and meditation as stress reduction measures. Concerning her diet, the patient adheres predominantly to vegetarian principles.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
On physical examination, she exhibited tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and examination with a tongue depressor noted swelling and erythema of the base of her tongue area and the arytenoids, raising suspicion for her underlying condition.

LABORATORY DATA
Pertinent results indicated marked elevation in white blood counts with neutrophili, consistent with an acute bacterial infection. The patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was found to be markedly elevated. Computed tomography imaging was suggestive of a significantly involved airway with substantial risk for rapid clinical degradation and potential airway compromise.

HOSPITAL COURSE
The immediate priority was securing an uncomplicated airway, necessitating a procedure under monitored anesthesia care with careful spontaneous ventilation anesthesia for her endotracheal intubation. A prolonged recovery under anesthesia was anticipated for the patient, due to potential irritation caused to the vocal cords during manipulation and existing inflammation. Despite these complexities, airway stabilization was successfully managed with antibiotic treatments, pain management protocol, supportive care, and the assistance of speech pathology to facilitate healing, thereby resulting in resolution without the development of any lasting complications or necessity for a longer-term care transition post-recovery from prolonged general inhalation agent induced recovery.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute asthma exacerbation

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Lisa Rodriguez is a 26-year-old preschool teacher who presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing. She reported that her symptoms began two days prior following a weekend trip to a local farm with her fiancé. Initially, she attributed the symptoms to seasonal allergies, which she experiences each spring, but her condition progressively worsened, leading her to visit the ER. Prior to this episode, she had been using over-the-counter antihistamines, which offered no relief. In the ER, she was diagnosed with an asthma exacerbation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Lisa has a history of mild persistent asthma diagnosed at age 10, with previous exacerbations occurring mainly in childhood. She also has allergic rhinitis. She is aware of her triggers, which include pollen, dust, and animal dander. She typically manages her asthma with an albuterol inhaler as needed but admits to inconsistent use over the past year.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Lisa lives in a small apartment in the city with her fiancé. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol frequently. She is physically active, typically running three times a week, and follows a balanced diet. During vacations and holidays, she enjoys hiking and outdoor activities. Currently, she has a pet cat that stays with her mother due to her dander allergy.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, Lisa appeared in mild respiratory distress. Her vital signs included a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, heart rate of 102 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Auscultation revealed bilateral wheezes throughout the lung fields. There were no signs of cyanosis or accessory muscle use.

LABORATORY DATA: Her blood work in the ER was largely unremarkable aside from a mild leukocytosis. A chest X-ray was performed, which showed clear lungs with no evidence of pneumonia or effusion.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Lisa was treated in the ER with a nebulized bronchodilator, which resulted in marked improvement in her respiratory status. <ER_VISIT><DIAG:ASTHMA_EXACERBATION><TREAT:BRONCHODILATOR> She was also given a short course of oral prednisone to manage inflammation. She was observed for a few hours, during which her oxygen saturation returned to 98% on room air and her respiratory symptoms significantly improved.

Lisa was discharged with a follow-up appointment scheduled with her primary care physician in seven days to evaluate her asthma management plan and ensure optimal control moving forward. She was advised to maintain regular usage of her albuterol inhaler, particularly during exposure to known triggers, and to start using a daily inhaled corticosteroid as part of her long-term management plan. Her follow-up visit will also assess her response to the changes in her medication regimen.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia and acute respiratory failure

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Watson, a 67-year-old retired electrician, was admitted to the hospital following an ER visit for difficulty breathing and a persistent cough. Symptoms began about ten days prior with a mild fever, fatigue, and a dry cough which progressively worsened. Five days before admission, he noted increased shortness of breath and productive cough with yellow-green sputum. Concerned about the escalating symptoms, his daughter urged him to visit the emergency room. Severe respiratory distress was evident upon arrival, prompting immediate treatment with antibiotics, bronchodilators, and supplemental oxygen in the ER.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Watson has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) diagnosed five years ago, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He has been on a stable regimen of inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators for COPD management. His hypertension is well-controlled with lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Watson resides in a suburban community with his wife. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history, quitting approximately ten years ago. He enjoys gardening and spends significant time outdoors. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Watson appeared dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation was 88% on room air, improving to 94% with supplemental oxygen. Lung auscultation revealed bilateral crackles and wheezes, more pronounced in the right lower lobe. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable, with normal heart sounds. He was afebrile, with blood pressure at 142/85 mmHg, and a heart rate of 102 beats per minute.

LABORATORY DATA: Admission laboratory findings showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15,000/mm³ and elevated C-reactive protein. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.32. Chest X-ray indicated right lower lobe consolidation and left lung infiltrates consistent with pneumonia.

HOSPITAL COURSE: During hospitalization, Mr. Watson was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, initially piperacillin-tazobactam, transitioning to oral levofloxacin upon clinical improvement. His respiratory status gradually improved with aggressive supportive care, including oxygen therapy and respiratory physiotherapy. He was weaned off supplemental oxygen by day four. A follow-up chest X-ray demonstrated resolution of consolidation. Given his underlying COPD, a pulmonology consult recommended an adjustment in his inhaled medications to prevent future exacerbations.

Upon stabilization and improvement, Mr. Watson was deemed medically stable for discharge and transitioned to a short-term pulmonary rehabilitation program to strengthen his respiratory function and improve overall endurance. At the followup visit two weeks post-hospitalization, Mr. Watson reported feeling significantly better with only mild exertional dyspnea. He was encouraged to continue the pulmonary rehab exercises and manage his COPD carefully to prevent recurrent episodes.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The patient, a 65-year-old retired teacher, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute on chronic kidney injury, likely caused by a combination of medications and dehydration.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient reported a two-day history of nausea and vomiting, leading to a decreased oral intake. Prior to admittance, the patient experienced a lack of energy and had not been able to keep up with daily activities, such as walking the dog or volunteering at the local library.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Medically, the patient is a complex individual with a past history of atrial fibrillation and chronic kidney disease. For the past five years, the patient has been managed by a nephrologist and has had issues with high potassium levels due to certain medications the nephrologist has prescribed. Additionally, the patient had bypass surgery for coronary artery disease three years ago. However, the patient remained fairly active prior to this illness and enjoyed time with grandchildren, which included hiking and other outdoor activities.

SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient worked for most of his life and currently lives alone. After his heart condition, the patient became more determined than before to live life without too much of it revolving around medicine and hospital visits.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
A physical examination was significant for tachypnea, a blood pressure of one twenty over eighty and a pulse of one hundred and twenty beats per minute upon hospital admittance, showing an improvement compared to initial admittance to the hospital emergency room.

LABORATORY DATA
Laboratory data was notable for elevated creatine phosphokinase at one eighty and mild hyponatremia and a serum potassium level of five dot two upon hospital admittance, reflecting possible but treatable effects from dehydration.

HOSPITAL COURSE
In response to the findings on the lab reports and based on clinical decision making of multiple providers the initial step to treating him consisted of intravenous fluids and stopping the medications most noted for potential kidney impact when dehydrated.

Patient Record: Hospital Encounter

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Exacerbation of Congestive Heart Failure

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 78-year-old retired schoolteacher who presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath over the past three days. She reported a 2-week history of increasing leg swelling and orthopnea, requiring two pillows for sleep. She noted a decrease in daytime activity due to fatigue and a 10-pound weight gain over the last month. She denied chest pain but described a persistent cough productive of white sputum. Her daughter, who accompanied her, mentioned adherence issues with medications over the past two months.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a longstanding history of hypertension, well-controlled with lisinopril, and type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. She was diagnosed with congestive heart failure five years ago and has been on a stable medication regimen, including metoprolol and furosemide. Her surgical history includes a cholecystectomy performed 15 years ago.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives alone in a single-story home but has frequent visits from her daughter. She quit smoking 30 years ago and does not consume alcohol. Her diet involves high sodium intake despite recommendations from her healthcare provider. She remains engaged in her local gardening club and regularly attends church services.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared in mild respiratory distress. She is afebrile, with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 96 beats per minute. Respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation at 89% on room air. Lung examination revealed bilateral crackles at the bases. The cardiovascular exam showed a displaced PMI and a regular rhythm without murmurs. The abdomen was distended with shifting dullness, and bilateral pitting edema was noted up to the knees.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory tests revealed a BNP level of 1050 pg/mL, indicating heart failure exacerbation. Renal function tests showed creatinine at 1.8 mg/dL, displaying a slight worsening from the baseline of 1.4 mg/dL. Electrolytes were within normal limits. A chest X-ray indicated pulmonary congestion with cardiomegaly. An echocardiogram confirmed an ejection fraction of 35%, consistent with prior assessments.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward for diuresis and further management of heart failure. Furosemide was administered intravenously with significant diuresis achieved, resulting in symptomatic relief and reduced edema. Metoprolol was continued at the adjusted dose, and lisinopril was temporarily held due to renal function concerns. The patient's weight decreased by 8 pounds over three days, correlating with clinical improvement. The patient was educated on dietary modifications and the importance of medication adherence before discharge. A follow-up appointment with her cardiologist was scheduled for two weeks post-discharge.

A sixty-two year old retired librarian named Carolyn presented to the hospital with symptoms of dizziness and unsteadiness that began several hours prior to admit. Her admission diagnosis was listed as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

 Carolyn reported that the symptoms started after she went to bed with symptoms resolving upon sitting, she stated that she recently began practicing yoga to help with flexibility. She also admitted to occasional drowsiness after starting an over-the-counter medication several months ago for sleep. Her symptoms gradually increased when altering head positions, which prompted her to visit the emergency room.

Her past medical history revealed Carolyn to be generally in good health, having managed hypertension with medication, but no other active medical problems except for hypothyroidism and arthritis, both diagnosed several years prior for which she takes a stable dose of levothyroxine. In addition to hypertension Carolyn's past hospital admission was for pneumonia when she was 50 which resolved after a hospital stay for several days.

 Carolyn had never been married and had worked as librarian most of her life. As regards her habits, Carolyn never abused any substances and smoked about a cigarette per summer on rare social occasions with close friends at outdoor gatherings, however most of her time was spent at the library or with family and very little time for social events outside this routine.

A thorough examination of Carolyn revealed mild instability during neurological assessment and some diminished response in hearing, with the left tympanic more dull, otherwise all the other system appeared normal, her heart and lung sounds, her cardiovascular system and musculosktletal seemed unremarkable. Blood chemistry work, including renal and liver function along full metabolic panel were within the limit of error for this test on admission.

Her lab tests for anemia or other metabolic cause was checked on an empty stomach for complete lab evaluation and the patient stayed for monitoring under care during one-day admission and underwent an ECT scan and head magnetic resonance with and without contrast after she presented symptoms that raised suspicion to possibly have some more ominous cause including small central nerve stroke versus peripheral cause given age related possible causes.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS 
Severe gastrointestinal bleeding was diagnosed upon arrival to the hospital emergency department, requiring careful observation over several hours, and the initiation of aggressive treatments to stabilize the patient.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Her past treatments included coumadin for nearly eight years, however after repeated lab values revealed sub-therapeutic prothrombin times she transitioned onto an alternate treatment using rivaroxaban for improved INR control.

A homemaker by occupation and avid volunteer at several charitable organizations, the socially-active  Mrs Rodriguez resides locally with family within driving distance who could assist during her extended convalescence post-discharge. Despite long-standing personal and family smoking addiction, neither she, nor husband have engaged in that habit for nearly eight years.

PHysical examination showed signs of possible early heart failure along with bilateral pedal swelling of  three months or longer duration on both her lower extremities.

laboratory data 
reveals abnormal elevated serum levels including creatinine (3.2 mg per dL). Complete hemGRAM indicates mild to moderate chronic cytopenias (platelet, hemoglobin).

hospital Course.

Multiple large transfusions followed during subsequent recovery from procedure in recovery.
