ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS  
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  
James Carter, a 58-year-old male, presented to the emergency department complaining of increased shortness of breath, wheezing, and productive cough with greenish sputum for the past three days. He reported that his symptoms began worsening following an upper respiratory tract infection. Despite using his prescribed inhalers more frequently, his symptoms did not improve. James, a retired truck driver, noted that he tends to have similar episodes during the winter months but none as severe as this.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
James has a significant history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diagnosed 10 years ago. He also has a history of hypertension, which is well managed with amlodipine. James had a myocardial infarction five years ago and subsequently underwent angioplasty. He is on daily aspirin and atorvastatin for secondary prevention.

SOCIAL HISTORY  
James is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history, having quit five years ago following his heart attack. He lives with his wife and occasionally babysits his grandchildren. James does not consume alcohol but is known to chew tobacco. He rarely exercises, citing difficulty breathing and joint pains as primary barriers.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
Upon examination, James appeared in mild respiratory distress. His temperature was 99°F, blood pressure 148/88 mmHg, pulse rate 92 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation at 89% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed diffuse wheezing bilaterally with decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable except for a slight S4 gallop.

LABORATORY DATA  
Complete blood count revealed a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm³, suggestive of an infection. The C-reactive protein level was elevated. Arterial blood gas analysis showed mild respiratory acidosis with partial pressure of carbon dioxide at 48 mmHg and partial pressure of oxygen at 60 mmHg on room air. A chest X-ray showed hyperinflated lungs and no new infiltrates, consistent with COPD.

HOSPITAL COURSE  
James was admitted to the medical ward for further management of his exacerbation. He was started on intravenous antibiotics and corticosteroids, and regular nebulization with bronchodilators was initiated. Supplemental oxygen was provided to maintain saturation above 92%. During the hospital stay, a respiratory therapist worked with James on breathing exercises. After three days of treatment, his symptoms significantly improved, and he was able to ambulate without shortness of breath. Before discharge, a pulmonologist reviewed his inhaler technique and recommended the addition of a long-acting muscarinic antagonist to his regimen. James was discharged on the fifth hospital day with instructions to follow up in the outpatient clinic in two weeks.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: A 28-year-old male, John Doe, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of progressively worsening abdominal pain, initially periumbilical and now localized in the right lower quadrant. He reported associated nausea and anorexia, but no emesis or diarrhea. He denied any similar previous episodes or recent travel. John is otherwise healthy and did not take over-the-counter analgesics prior to presentation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: John's medical history is significant for bronchial asthma since childhood, well-managed with inhaled corticosteroids as needed. No prior surgeries, no history of allergies, and he is up-to-date on vaccinations including the annual influenza vaccine.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John is a software engineer living in an urban area. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol socially, approximately 2-3 drinks per week. He exercises regularly, attending a local gym three times a week. He lives with his partner and does not have any children. No significant family history of gastrointestinal diseases was noted.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, John was afebrile, with vital signs showing mild tachycardia. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant, with rebound tenderness and guarding. Rovsing’s sign was positive, and bowel sounds were diminished. No other significant findings were noted on cardiovascular or respiratory examination.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³, predominantly neutrophils. C-reactive protein was elevated. Liver function tests, serum electrolytes, and renal function tests were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: John was admitted with a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed an enlarged and inflamed appendix. He was started on intravenous fluids, and antibiotics (ceftriaxone and metronidazole) were initiated pre-operatively. John underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy the following morning. Post-operatively, he recovered well with significant improvement in symptoms. His pain was managed effectively with oral analgesics, and he was mobilized and on a regular diet by post-operative day two. John was discharged on post-operative day three with oral antibiotics to complete a course, and with instructions to avoid strenuous activities for two weeks.

Follow-up with the surgical outpatient clinic was arranged for two weeks post-discharge, at which time John's incision sites were healing well with no signs of infection. John returned to work after his follow-up appointment and continued with a full recovery.

She described her symptoms as a sudden, tight feeling in her chest accompanied by wheezing and difficulty catching her breath. She mentioned using her rescue inhaler multiple times with only temporary relief. Erica noted that she had been attending a concert the evening before, where there was visible smoke from pyrotechnics, which possibly triggered her symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Erica has a history of asthma diagnosed at the age of six, managed primarily with a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler. She has experienced one or two minor episodes each year typically related to seasonal changes or respiratory infections. No previous hospitalizations for asthma. She denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, or cardiovascular diseases.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Erica lives in an urban apartment with her partner and a pet cat. She does not smoke and reports consuming alcohol socially, about 1-2 drinks per week. She is physically active, participating in yoga and occasional cycling. She works full time as a graphic designer at a local firm. Erica’s family history is unremarkable for respiratory diseases.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Erica was found to be in mild respiratory distress. Her respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute with accessory muscle use. An expiratory wheeze was audible on auscultation. Oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Heart rate was slightly elevated at 101 beats per minute, and blood pressure was 110/72 mmHg. No cyanosis was noted, and other systems were within normal limits.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial arterial blood gas analysis showed mild hypoxemia with a pH of 7.38, PaCO2 of 42 mmHg, and PaO2 of 68 mmHg. A complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were unremarkable. Chest X-ray showed no evidence of pneumonia or other acute processes.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Erica was admitted to the medical ward for observation and treatment of her asthma exacerbation. She received nebulized bronchodilator therapy and systemic corticosteroids, which resulted in significant improvement of her symptoms. She was also educated on the proper use of inhalers and the importance of avoiding known environmental triggers. During her hospital stay, her respiratory status stabilized, and she was discharged home with a follow-up appointment scheduled with a pulmonologist in two weeks. A treatment plan including the continued use of bronchodilators and an inhaled corticosteroid was emphasized to prevent future episodes. Erica expressed understanding and commitment to follow-up care, indicating she had set reminders for her next medical appointment to ensure adherence to the treatment regimen.

AD MISSION DIAGNOSIS 
The patient, a fifty-five year old female botanist, was admitted with a primary diagnosis of acute kidney injury secondary to severe dehydration. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
She presented to the emergency department with a two day history of nausea, vomiting and increasing fatigue. The symptoms had been insidious in onset but worsened significantly over the past twenty-four hours. The patient reported that two weeks ago she had started a trial course of a novel experimental drug, sanguinarine, under investigative trials for its anti-inflammatory properties as an intervention in the management of autoimmune arthropathy. However, due to an unpredictable and poorly explained reaction shortly after initiation of this experimental medication, characterized by diffuse skin rashes and intense episodes of diarrhea, her doctors advised an immediate cessation of the regimen. Since discontinuation, she began noticing increased thirst and decreased urine output leading her to seek urgent medical review when the symptoms deteriorated further.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
Her medical history is relevant for controlled hypertension and rheumatoid arthritis. Regular follow ups with rheumatologist had resulted in adjustment to and initiation of various drugs such as DMards including hydroxychloroquine and low dose oral prednisone in controlling arthritic symptoms while keeping blood pressures controlled using lisinopril. She was known non smoker and social moderate alcohol drinker but has been a passionate gardener throughout her lifespan.

SOCIAL HISTORY 
Further discussions indicated an extensive history working closely and avid fascination towards various flowering plants in particular that are common across central america for research projects related on their unique chemical make-up and possible uses. She was widowed in the last five years with a strong and present adult only child for support structure, residing in their suburban house.  

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 
Upon examination, this relatively well nourished female in evident moderate distress displayed vital signs of decreased blood pressure 85/50 with a tachycardiac pulsation in a narrow window range just over a one hundred beat a min heart range with elevated core temperatures at just greater than a  hundred and 1 in a pattern possibly suggestive more as a function related response likely secondary effect resultant of ongoing possible nephro logical issue and its consequence dehydration, rather than that associated commonly alongside pyrexial illnesses 

LABORATORY DATA 
Subsequent laboratory assessments revealed a rise in her creatine at levels just in excess exceeding more than twice and also slightly raised values associated to hepatically driven enzymes indicating likely secondary effect damage as direct consequence likely resultant to both renal injury alongside and as part an unexplained unpredictable  effect due presumably to sanguinarine drug therapy.

HOSPITAL COURSE 
Over the subsequent two days an improvement in renal indices accompanied a gradually rising urine output subsequent hydration therapy aggressive iv hydration alongside an observed and clinically noted stabilisation in BP measurements were seen post intensive nephrological support in the renal high dependancy ward with close eye on the monitoring and eventual discontinuation when the patient showed full functional potential with recovery noted.  It appears that her trial with sanguinarine as part the autoimmune arthopathy disease drug had presented with possibly unforeseeable and potentially damaging  impact as an unpredicted and unknown effect of said experimental medication therapy which fortunately seemed fully resolved and reversed through medical management and supportive therapies during the course her admission and care provided here throughout

Patient Name: Elaine Smith  
Age: 68  
Sex: Female  
Occupation: Retired School Teacher  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Pneumonia

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mrs. Elaine Smith was admitted to the hospital following a visit to the emergency room with a three-day history of progressive shortness of breath. She initially experienced fatigue and a mild cough and noted that her breathing became increasingly labored, especially upon exertion. This escalation in symptoms prompted <ONSET_SHORTNESS_OF_BREATH> her daughter to drive her to the ER. At the ER, Mrs. Smith was <ER_VISIT> evaluated, and a chest X-ray confirmed a diagnosis of pneumonia <DIAG:PNEUMONIA>. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mrs. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension, for which she takes Lisinopril, and Type 2 Diabetes, managed with Metformin. She has well-controlled hyperlipidemia with Atorvastatin, and a history of osteoarthritis in her knees, for which she occasionally takes Ibuprofen.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mrs. Smith is a retired school teacher who lives alone in a small suburban neighborhood. She is a nonsmoker, having quit 15 years ago, and consumes alcohol infrequently, usually a glass of wine during social occasions. She enjoys gardening and is active in her local community center, where she teaches literacy classes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was in mild respiratory distress. Her temperature was 100.2°F, blood pressure 136/82 mmHg, pulse 92 bpm, and oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. Pulmonary auscultation revealed crackles in the right lower lobe, and there were no signs of cyanosis or wheezing.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 13,000 cells/mcL, indicating an infection. C-reactive protein was elevated. Blood glucose was slightly elevated at 160 mg/dL. Electrolytes were within normal limits. A sputum culture grew Streptococcus pneumoniae.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mrs. Smith was started on intravenous antibiotics, specifically Ceftriaxone and Azithromycin <TREAT:ANTIBIOTICS>, and supplemental oxygen was administered to maintain her oxygen saturation above 95%. Her blood sugar levels were monitored closely, and her diabetes medications adjusted accordingly. Over the next few days, her respiratory status improved significantly, and she was weaned off supplemental oxygen. Physiotherapy was included to aid her recovery and address her general deconditioning. After showing good clinical improvement, she was discharged home with a prescription for oral antibiotics to complete a 10-day course and instructions to follow up with her primary care physician in one week <FOLLOWUP_VISIT>.

Mrs. Smith was advised to get plenty of rest, maintain adequate hydration, and monitor her blood sugar levels closely. She expressed understanding of her discharge instructions and emphasized her commitment to complete the prescribed antibiotic regimen.

Patient Record: Samira Alvarez

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Diabetic Ketoacidosis  

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Samira Alvarez is a 19-year-old college student who presented to the emergency department with a four-day history of progressively worsening fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia, and abdominal pain. She reports a significant increase in thirst and urination over the past week, which she initially attributed to the stress and dietary changes due to her final exams. However, when she developed abdominal pain and nausea, she decided to seek medical care. Blood glucose was found to be markedly elevated upon initial evaluation, prompting her admission for further management.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Samira was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus at age 14. She generally managed her condition well with insulin therapy, although recent academic pressures caused some lapses in her routine care. She has been admitted once previously for a similar diabetic crisis when initially diagnosed. Her immunizations are up to date, and she denies any known allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Samira is a sophomore in college, majoring in chemistry. She resides in a dormitory with her peers and occasionally consumes alcohol but denies tobacco or illicit drug use. Her family lives abroad, and she maintains regular contact with them through video calls. She actively participates in the school’s debate team and enjoys hiking during her free time.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Samira appeared fatigued and dehydrated. Her vital signs showed tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm and mild tachypnea, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Her blood pressure was 98/64 mmHg. She exhibited dry mucous membranes and had mild abdominal tenderness upon palpation without rebound or guarding.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial labs revealed a blood glucose level of 450 mg/dL, serum bicarbonate of 15 mmol/L, and an elevated anion gap. Urinalysis confirmed significant ketonuria and glucosuria. Electrolyte imbalances included mild hypokalemia, which was addressed during her hospital course.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Samira was treated with an insulin drip, aggressive intravenous fluid rehydration, and potassium replacement. Over the first 24 hours, her blood glucose levels stabilized, and acidosis resolved. She was transitioned to her home insulin regimen once oral intake was resumed and tolerated. She responded well to treatment and was discharged with clear instructions for insulin dosing adjustments during times of increased physical or academic stress to prevent future episodes. A follow-up visit with her endocrinologist was scheduled a week post-discharge.

Unfortunately, Samira experienced symptom recurrence due to missed insulin doses during a particularly strenuous exam week a month later. This led to an ER visit where she was treated for mild hyperglycemia and quickly released with reinforced counseling on diabetes management and stress reduction techniques. She was encouraged to utilize available campus health resources and peer support groups to maintain better control of her diabetes amidst her busy academic life.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS  
Unstable angina with suspected coronary artery disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  
John Smith, a 52-year-old male accountant, was admitted to the hospital following an emergency room visit. He experienced sudden onset chest pain while at work two days ago, described as a tight, squeezing sensation in the center of his chest, radiating to his left arm. The pain drove him to visit the emergency department, where initial workup suggested angina. He received nitroglycerin, which alleviated his symptoms, prompting further evaluation for coronary artery disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
John has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which have been managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. He also has a past history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He denies any history of diabetes, specific cardiac conditions, or previous surgeries.

SOCIAL HISTORY  
John lives with his spouse in a suburban area and works full-time in a sedentary job as an accountant. He is physically inactive, mentioning occasional light walks over the weekends. He drinks alcohol socially, about two to three drinks per week, and does not use recreational drugs. As mentioned, he quit smoking five years ago after smoking a pack a day for nearly two decades.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
On physical examination, John appears his stated age and is in no apparent distress. Vital signs are significant for a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1 and S2 heart sounds without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and without organomegaly.

LABORATORY DATA  
Laboratory studies conducted in the ER revealed normal complete blood count and electrolytes. Cardiac enzymes were within normal ranges, and an initial ECG showed ST segment depression in the inferolateral leads, consistent with ischemic changes. Further stress test during hospitalization showed positive exercise tolerance with ST segment depression at moderate levels of exertion, corroborating the diagnosis of angina.

HOSPITAL COURSE  
During his hospital stay, John underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a 70% occlusion of the right coronary artery. He was started on aspirin and a beta-blocker and counseled on lifestyle modifications, including a supervised exercise program, dietary changes, and stress management. The cardiothoracic team discussed the possibility of elective percutaneous coronary intervention, which is being considered. Upon discharge, John was stable, pain-free on a regimen of nitroglycerin as needed, with plans for a follow-up visit with his cardiologist in one week to reassess his symptoms and discuss intervention options further. John was advised to adhere strictly to his medication regimen and report any recurrent symptoms immediately.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 67-year-old retired male factory worker who presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of worsening shortness of breath, increased sputum production, and cough. He noted that these symptoms were aggravated by exertion and were unrelieved by his usual bronchodilator treatment. He reported increased accessory muscle use, and his wife observed that he had been more fatigued than usual. The patient denied chest pain, fever, or hemoptysis. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient's medical history is significant for COPD, diagnosed eight years ago. He has had multiple hospital admissions for COPD exacerbations over the past three years. He also has a history of hypertension, managed with lisinopril. There is no history of heart disease or diabetes. He is a former smoker, having quit five years ago, with a 40-pack-year history. He does not have significant medication allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a lifelong resident of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He is a former factory worker who retired five years ago due to health issues related to his COPD. He lives in a single-story home with his wife. He enjoys fishing in a nearby river and spends his time tending to his garden. He quit smoking after his COPD diagnosis but still occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. He has a daughter who lives nearby and visits on weekends.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On physical examination, the patient appeared in moderate respiratory distress, using accessory muscles to breathe. He was alert and oriented. Blood pressure was 140/85 mmHg, pulse 98/min, respiratory rate 24/min, and SpO2 88% on room air and 94% on 2L via nasal cannula. Lung auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally with scattered wheezes and rhonchi. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable, with regular heart rhythm and no murmurs.

LABORATORY DATA: Arterial blood gas analysis showed pH 7.36, PaCO2 54 mmHg, and PaO2 65 mmHg on supplemental oxygen. Complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13,000/uL. Electrolytes were within normal limits. Chest X-ray revealed hyperinflated lungs and fibrosis indicative of chronic changes but no acute infiltrates or consolidation. Spirometry prior to admission showed FEV1 at 45% predicted.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the medical ward, and treatment was initiated for acute COPD exacerbation. He received nebulized bronchodilators and systemic corticosteroids. Antibiotic therapy with azithromycin was started due to the increased sputum production and leukocytosis. Over the course of the hospital stay, the patient's symptoms gradually improved. Supplemental oxygen was tapered as his respiratory status stabilized. Respiratory therapy sessions were provided for pulmonary rehabilitation. By day four, the patient was stable on room air with improved exercise tolerance. He was educated on smoking cessation reinforcement and the importance of medication adherence. Prior to discharge, a follow-up appointment with his pulmonologist was scheduled, and he was encouraged to engage in a pulmonary rehabilitation program.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS
The 68 year old retired mechanic was brought to the hospital by his wife after a sudden episode of dizziness and confusion, and was diagnosed with severe dehydration and hyperglycemia upon arrival.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient's condition started about a month ago with increasing thirst and fatigue, gradually worsening to the point where he was unable to keep fluids down. His wife reported that he has been taking metformin, though the dosage and administration schedule could not be confirmed. A week prior to admission, he started feeling weak and disoriented, particularly in the early mornings.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient has had hypertension for ten years, managed with a combination of lifestyle changes and medication. Three years ago, he was also started on simvastatin due to elevated cholesterol levels. Of note is a history of renal stone surgery five years ago. He has also been experiencing intermittent low back pain that worsened over time, managed with acetaminophen as needed.

SOCIAL HISTORY
A heavy smoker until five years ago, the patient stopped due to severe breathing difficulties. His occupation exposed him to high lead levels and various chemicals throughout his years of service. He reported an average alcohol intake but has noticed reduced alcohol consumption over the years due to general decline in social interactions. Family history is remarkable for cardiac disease with his sister dying of congestive heart failure two years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Upon physical exam, blood pressure was elevated at 170/100 mmHg and pulse was high at 105 beats per minute. Notable laboratory findings revealed severely imbalanced electrolyte panel due to poor diet and vomiting, with marked potassium deficiencies and signs suggestive of impending renal injury. Patient's sensorium was altered; however, pupillary reactions, motor strength, and sensations were within normal limits, albeit limited due to lack of mobility and patient pain.

LABORATORY.DATA
His CBC results revealed anemia and high leukocytosis indicative of acute or chronic inflammation or infection. Renal profiles showed creatinine at elevated levels. Further work up is pending to identify specific renal insults causing these changes.

HOSPITAL COURSE
Patient was put on iv fluids hydration therapy, managed for dehydration with correction of electrolyte disturbances, especially hypotension being monitored throughout. An episode of acute drop in blood sugars, likely due to changes in IV fluid, necessitated administration of dextrose. Hypertension is being more aggressively managed with multiple meds adjusted. Given the elevated sugar at the outset and the symptoms presented we are still considering adding additional meds for better monitoring.
